data.name: Diseases
entries: The Dungeon Master's Guide provides three example disease to use in a D&D game which are simple to implement and easy to adapt to suit one's individual needs, but lack complexity or versatility. The diseases described below delve deeper into what a fantasy disease can be, and how it can be implemented into a story or campaign.

While the Medicine skill is always useful when dealing with diseases, some focus has been given to alternative skills to use when diagnosing or treating these diseases. Typically in D&D a disease can be cured easily with magic at relatively low levels. In the examples below, the methods of treated are more difficulty or require additional steps to make the usual remedies effective, not only to make these conditions more dangerous to parties with easy access to disease-curing magic, but also to evoke the tense and dramatic process that medicine can often be in fiction.

In addition, some of these entries serve multiple purposes rather than simply being negative stat penalties to apply to players. For example, applying Blightpus to a horde of weak enemies can make them more dangerous to cleave through in close quarters, while Shroud Vine confers both penalties and desirable boons to those infected. At the end of this section are roll tables of plot hooks for each listed disease to use as inspiration for stories involving them.
Each disease subheading is divided into the following parts:
First the entry gives the most common name for the disease, but some disease may be known by multiple names or have a different name in other settings.
{@b Symptoms} describes the visible effects of the disease to an outside observer as well as what an infected creature might feel or be aware of.
{@b Effects} details the effects of the disease in game terms and how it affects an infected creature's in-game statistics.
{@b Contracting} outlines how a creature becomes infected in game terms, as well as an overview of situations where one is likely to come into contact with the disease.
{@b Diagnosis} gives suggestions on ability checks one could use to identify the disease or gain more information about it.
{@b Treatment} describes how to cure the disease or how to alleviate some of its effects in game terms.

entries.name: Where are all the healers?
entries: In the magical worlds of D&D, healing disease is simple and can be done with a single spell. Many large towns and cities have divine spellcasters available, and smaller settlements can call for aid. Wilderness and tribal communities may have druids in their ranks who are also competent healers. With healing magic everywhere, how does an outbreak of disease even happen? How can you run exciting and horrifying stories of plague-ridden lands when by all rights this should be a trivial matter to resolve?

The solution used for many of the diseases presented in this document is to simply make some of the diseases themselves more difficult to heal. But this may not work for your story. Perhaps you want the disease to be an integral part of the setting, but not something the players need to worry about for long, since the real-life countermeasures against disease spread such as staying at home aren't condusive to adventure. Or perhaps you simply don't want to have the hassle of repeatedly running complex cures that will slow down the pace of the game. In situations like this, the formal rules and their streamlined cures might work for you, but creates a problem when trying to explain why everyone can't do this. There are other possible explanations though:
The affected settlement is isolated and healers can't reach it, or the locals can't easily leave to call for aid.

items: There are healers available, but not enough. They are being overwhelmed by the patient load, or the infection is simply too widespread to stop.
Political, religious, or racial divides means that certain demographics aren't being treated or are at a lower priority for recieving treatment.
Healers are split between treating this outbreak and providing aid for some other event, such as a war or natural disaster.
Healers are handling individual cases but can't address the underlying cause of the outbreak, such as contaminated water, biological warfare, attacks by infected monsters, or a magical curse.
Supplies needed to properly equip doctors and spellcasters are scarce.
A powerful authority is ignoring or blocking aid to the infected because doing so would detract from some political goal.

What if the players have one or more healers in their ranks, and wish to spend days performing healing services? It may be prudent to simply allow them to do this. Players have limited resources, and spending time healing means they have fewer resources available to confront danger, so this course of action comes with risk.

entries.name: Plot Hook Tables
entries: Below are roll tables with a few suggested plot hooks or story ideas that incorporate the diseases described in this document. These are only suggestions and don't represent the whole scope of how a disease can be used in a campaign.
Glass Delusion and Glass Transmogrification use the same table.

entries.caption: Blightpus
rows: Miners are attacked by monsters infected with Blightpus, suggesting that their tunnels have crossed with caves that reach the underdark.

An outbreak of Blightpus in a large town leads to some areas being quarantined, with the quarantined areas becoming rife with crime and adventurers are denied access to important people or places in the quarantine zones.
Cultists to gods of disease or demons intentionally infect themselves with Blightpus to burn their foes in battle.
A sharp surge in Blightpuff growth in nearby wilderness leads locals to fear that a powerful monster such as a dragon has claimed the area as their territory.

entries.caption: Boiling Blood
rows: Residents of an infected settlement seek the aid of a powerful mage who can control the weather, the cold temperatures allowing them to treat people en-masse.
A healer accidentally kills a Boiling Blood victim via hypothermia while attempting treatment, and tries to cover it up.
A red dragon has laired near a town, and infected water runs down from its mountain. Townsfolk want the dragon either slain or cured to halt the source of the infections.
The scent of cooked flesh coming from the mass graves of Boiling Blood victims during an outbreak has attracted monsters to come and dig up the bodies.

entries.caption: Cannibal Cravings
rows: A  suspected contamination of Cannibal Craving in an expedition's water supply causes paranoia and violent conflict.
A cult of demon worshippers see the infection as a blessing from their deity and seek to spread it.
A noble with Cannibal Craving murders and eats poor people in secret, covertly serving human meat to guests.
A village is attacked nightly by frenzied animals infected with Cannibal Craving and seek aid in finding the source of the infection.

entries.caption: Contagious Troll Tumours
rows: An adventurer returns to town after a successful quest and starts boasting about their newfound healing powers in a local tavern, unaware of the risk.
Another monster contracted CTT and became more aggressive and confident from their enhanced healing.
A renowned hero owes their success to CTT but hides their face from public viewing as they are covered in tumours.
A troll ends up in an unlikely place (such as on a boat, in a locked prison cell, or a lord's manor) as a result of being born from a CTT victim.

entries.caption: Earwyrms
rows: An Earwyrm repeats a dangerous secret it heard while occupying a previous host, launching a search to find the source of the outbreak.
A stock of domesticated Earwyrms escapes, starting an infestation. Annoyed locals want the situation resolved by any means.
Players need to seek out an Earwyrm breeder so they can use the Earwyrms to their advantage against a Mind Flayer colony.
An Earwyrm host mistakes the creature's random mimicry for a cryptic supernatural portent.

entries.caption: Glass Delusion/Transmorgification
rows: A noble is secretly suffering from Glass Delusion, and is being blackmailed by someone who knows their secret.
Multiple cases of Glass Delusion in a single town pushes local authorities to investigate the possibility of a new potion black market
A hag curses the loved one of an adventurer with Glass Delusion in revenge for a slight against her.
A spellcaster's aid is needed for a quest, but they've become reclusive and paranoid due to suffering from Glass Delusion.

entries.caption: Shroud Vine
rows: Shroud Vine bushes appearing near a countryside village are seen as a bad omen, and the villagers hire adventurers to investigate the source.
An extremist druid intentionally infects people with Shroud Vine as punishment for perceived crimes until they can repay their wrongdoings by going on a quest.
A dungeon is guarded by swarms of plant creatures that can only be avoided by infecting oneself with Shroud Vine.
A settlement afflicted by a Shroud Vine outbreak is at odds with itself as conflict arises between those who want to cure the parasite and those who wish to coexist with it.

data.name: Curses
entries: This section details curses that can be used against players using the format for curses described in Van Richten's Guide to Ravenloft, where curses are generally described in three parts:
{@b Pronouncement} describes a threat or warning to the target of the curse, or anyone who might eventually fall foul to it.
{@b Burden} explains the effects of the curse in game terms.
{@b Resolution} explains how the curse might be ended.

entries.name: Bubblespeak
entries: This curse is often associated with fey for it's amusing nature. The affected creature dispenses bubbles from their mouth whenever they try to speak.

{@b Pronouncement:} This curse is levied at a creature that uses foul language in a highly inappropriate setting or who speaks ill of an important figure, and includes a reference to the old saying of 'washing your mouth out with soap'.

{@b Burden:} Whenever the cursed creature speaks, bubbles emerge from its mouth instead of words. If these bubbles are popped, the intended spoken words of the creature is emitted from it. Each bubble can contain a phrase up to 20 words long, so longer sentences create more bubble. The bubbles float upwards and are carried by even the softest breezes. Trying to pop a bubble requires a DC 13 Dexterity check.
{@b Resolution:} The curse instantly ends if the cursed creature uses soap to wash out the inside of its mouth.

entries.name: Cold of Heart
entries: This curse punishes callousness by trapping its victim in cold and loneliness with a literal heart of ice.
{@b Pronouncement:} Directed at someone who shows a lack of empathy. {@i 'For your cold heart, may you never feel warmth again.'}

{@b Burden:} The affected creature becomes unable to tolerate heat. If the creature is in an area with an ambient temperature higher than 0 degrees Celsius, it suffers the effects of {@hazard Extreme Heat}, but is immune to the effects of {@hazard Extreme Cold}. It gains a vulernability to fire damage, but is resistant to cold damage. Close contact with warm-blooded creatures, such as holding hands, grappling, or applying bandages, deals 1 fire damage to the cursed creature. The cursed creature itself has no body heat, and feels cold to the touch.
{@b Resolution:} Only an act of true kindness can break this curse.

entries.name: Collector
entries: A torment meant to punish greed, or to reduce a powerful foe into an ineffective eccentric. The cursed is driven to collect a certain kind of object.

{@b Pronouncement:} The pronouncement of this curse references a specific kind of object. It could be part of a set such as every shard of a broken sword or every coin from a stolen treasure, or it could be a kind of general object such as gems, spoons, mugs, dice, figurines, shoes, etc.

{@b Burden:} The affected creature feels a compulsion to collect the specific type of object. It refuses to relinquish objects of that type in its possession or allow objects in its posession to be destroyed. If another creature takes an object from the cursed creature's collection, it is magically compelled to retrieve the object by any means available to it. If the creature goes a day without gaining a new object for its collection, it must make a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw. On a failed save, it gains one form of indefinite madness (DMG page 260). For each day the creature goes without aquiring a new object for its collection, or retrieving an object taken from its collection, the DC increases by 1. After it gains a new object, the creature loses one form of madness every 24 hours and the saving throw against madness decreases by 1, as long as it continues to grow its collection.

{@b Resolution:} If the objects belong to a set, then returning the completed set to its rightful owner will lift the curse. Knowing this doesn't affect the cursed creature's behaviour: it still refuses to part with its collection.

For a generic object type, a creature can be freed from this curse if it destroys its own collection. Knowing this doesn't change its behaviour, it still refuses to part with its collection in any way, but it can still be freed if it unknowingly or accidentally destroys its collection, or if it is compelled to do so by magic. The creature has to destroy its own collection: another creature doing so won't relieve the burden of the curse.

entries.name: Duplicate
entries: This devious curse creates an exact duplicate of its target that can torment it in a variety of ways, from being a perfect match in battle to more insidious psychological attacks.

{@b Pronouncement:} This curse affects a creature that disturbs an ancient sarcophagus containing the soul of an ancient sorcerer, imprisoned fiend, or other villain. An inscription on the tomb warns against tampering, lest {@i 'You shall be your own worst enemy'}.

{@b Burden:} A creature affectd by this curse suffers no immediate effects. 24 hours after the curse takes effect, an exact duplicate of the cursed creature appears inside the sarcophagus. It has all the memories of the cursed, along with all of its game statistics and class features, but none of its equipment. However, it despises the cursed creature, and either wishes to ruin that creature's life and reputation, or wishes to kill and replace the cursed and live on in their place. If the duplicate is killed, another exact duplicate appears in the sarcophagus with all the memories of the previous duplicate.
{@b Resolution:} Killing the duplicate is only a temporary measure. The only way to end the curse is to re-seal the duplicate inside the sarcophagus.

entries.name: Eternally Forgotten
entries: As a punishment against the vainglorious, people cursed in this way can never achieve lasting recognition for their deeds, and even simply interpersonal relationships become impossible.
{@b Pronouncement:} This curse is directed at those who seek to be famous and commit terrible deeds to do so. Alternatively, it is directed at those who seek to rewrite history in their favour.

{@b Burden:} If the cursed creature isn't percieved by someone else for 10 consecutive minutues, that person forgets that the cursed person ever existed. Any illogical or impossible memories as a result of this are rationalised e.g. if the cursed creature did something significant, other people simply assume it didn't happen or that someone else did it. Other people tend to ignore or overlook evidence of the cursed person's existence unless it is explicticly pointed out to them.

{@b Resolution:} The curse is lifted if the cursed intentionally takes a course of action where they turn down the possibility of renown of their deeds, or allow someone else to take credit for their deeds. For example, they could destroy a statue erected in their honour, or claim that a companion actually slew a monster they killed.

entries.name: Horrid Reflection
entries: This curse is only noticable in the reflection of the afflicted, revealing their true nature.

{@b Pronouncement:} This curse is levied at someone with an evil nature whose wicked deeds are kept secret, usually by someone who knows the secret but cannot expose it, or whose testimony won't be believed.

{@b Burden:} The affected creature experiences a nightmare where they see themselves twisted in some monstrous way, such as appearing like a corpse, or having bestial features. When the creature awakens, it appears normal. However, it's reflection always appears as it did in the nightmare, to anyone who sees it. If the cursed creature sees its reflection, it becomes frightened of it. If it attacks its own reflection, such as by shattering a mirror or throwing a stone into water, the cursed creature takes 5 (1d10) psychic damage.

{@b Resolution:} Publically revealing the terrible secret or true nature of the afflicted does not end this curse. Instead, it causes the cursed creature's appearance to become like that of its reflection. Only true atonement, and a sincere change of heart, will end this curse. Once the creature's nature has changed, it ceases to be frightened by its reflection, and touching its reflection returns it to normal.

Alternatively, if the cursed creature reveals its own villainy, and fully embraces its deeds, then the curse's magic fails: the creature's wickedness is no longer a secret burden, thus this curse is no longer able to serve as a suitable punishment.

entries.name: Nonsense
entries: A tongue-twisting curse that inhibits a creature's ability to speak.

{@b Pronouncement:} This curse is caused by reading a cursed book written in bizzarre nonsensical script, and the words {@i 'The words of this book make no sense. Read them, and only Nonsense will make sense. So be Sensible'}.

The inside cover of the book warns against attempting to decipher the scrawl within. Merely observing the pages isn't enough, a creature only becomes cursed if they attempt to translate, decode, or otherwise interpret the words written on the pages.

{@b Burden:} The cursed creature cannot communicate with or understand any language. If it tries to speak or write, it only knows how to communicate in Nonsense. Translating nonsense is impossible: it has no translation, since it is completely nonsensical. Telepathy does not allow sensical communication either. However, two people cursed in this way can understand each other perfectly through any medium, even if they would normally not share any languages.

{@b Resolution:} A creature affected by this curse can still learn new languages, since languages it previously didn't understand are nonsensical to them and thus aren't affected by the curse's burden. Doing so creates sense out of nonsense, breaking the curse's magic. The same applies if it uses magic to be able to understand a language it previously couldn't (but not if another creature attempts to use magic to translate Nonsense, since that doesn't work, or if it uses magic to understand a language it is normally proficient in). Effects that completely disable a creature's ability to understand any kind of language (such as the Feeblemind spell) cause the curse to fail.

entries.name: Rat Lord
entries: Rats follow in the footsteps of the cursed, whether they like it or not. As rats bear diseases and pilfer food, this is likely to make the cursed unwelcome in humanoid settlements.

{@b Pronouncement:} This curse is usually directed at people of high social status or noble title, such as a knight or respected priest, and is done so in response to the individual committing some dishonourable deed not in line with the expectations of their station, with the utterance of {@i 'If you must act so wretchedly, then you deserve only to be a master of rats.'}

{@b Burden:} Rats within 300ft of the cursed creature become obsessed with them, and belive the cursed to be their Lord. These rats always know the direction to the Rat Lord and do their best to follow them or get near to them. Once a rat has been influenced in this way, the effect persists until the curse ends or the rat is more than 1 mile away from the Rat Lord for 24 hours. The rats will flee if attacked, but return as soon as they believe the danger to be over, and will only flee as far as they need to. Otherwise, their only goal is to be as close to their lord as possible at all times.

{@b Resolution:} The cursed must complete an act of nobility in line with their noble rank or social status, usually involving some sort of sacrifice or an act of great humility to prove themselves worthy of their station.

Alternatively, they can pass on the curse to someone else. A willing creature declares themselves the new Rat Lord, while the cursed makes a symbolic offering and humbles themself before the new lord.

entries.name: Two-Faced
entries: This curse is meant as an ironic punishment - and a horrifying transformation - towards traitors and deceivers.
{@b Pronouncement:} A person that suffers a terrible fate as result of a betrayal or lie told about them may lay this curse through their anguish and rage.

{@b Burden:} The cursed creature grows a second face on their body, usually out the back of their head. Whenever a creature tells a deliberate lie or tries to conceal the truth, the second face will reveal the truth. If the cursed creature tries to persuade someone of the truth or reveal a lie, then the second face will tell a lie.

{@b Resolution:} This curse ends when the cursed creature reveals the truth about the lie they told or proves the innocence of someone they betrayed. They must also reveal the presence of their curse, laying bare their two-faced nature.

entries.name: Vanity's Reward
entries: This curse is meant as an ironic punishment for those who overly value physical beauty.

{@b Pronouncement:} Usually directed at someone who has just committed a grevious act of vanity, or disparages someone for their superficial appearance, especially if that person is much mightier than their looks would suggest. {@i If beauty be all that concerns you, then let it be eternal, cast in stone!'}.

{@b Burden:} The cursed creature slowly begins to turn to stone. At first only visual indicators appear, with patches of stony-looking skin appearing on their body. After one day their speed is halved and they have disadvantage on all attack rolls, ability checks, and saving throws that use Dexterity. After two days their speed becomes 0 ft and can't benefit from increases to speed. After three days, they become Petrified.

{@b Resolution:} Magic that would cure petrification can't end this curse. Instead, it can only revert the creature to a partially cured state, as if it had the curse for one day. To permenantly end the curse, the creature must either intentionally deface its physical appearance, or intentionally appear in public in a humiliating or unappealing state.

entries.name: Wayward Shadow
entries: This curse is usually levied at those who committed a terrible crime and got away with it. The shadow of their deeds shall follow them forever.

{@b Pronouncement:} This curse is uttered by the victim of a crime who knows that the crime against them will never be solved, such as a dying person who knows there are no witnesses, or a marginalised beggar who knows that nobody will bother to seek justice on their behalf. {@i 'Your wickedness shall forever follow in your shadow, but remember: what happens in the dark always comes to the light.'}

{@b Burden:} The cursed creature's shadow becomes magically animated. Once a day, it can leave the cursed creature's side, and uses the statistics of a Shadow (Monster Manual pg 269). If it is destroyed or is away from the cursed creature for more than 24 hours, it reappears at the creature's side, as if it were an ordinary shadow. While independent, it seeks to commit evil acts similar to that committed by the cursed creature. It may also attempt to implicate the cursed creature in these crimes. At all other times, it appears to be an ordinary shadow, and cannot be detected by magic that would detect undead. While away, the cursed creature casts no shadow.

{@b Resolution:} The curse can lifted by applying the words of the pronouncement in a literal or figurative manner. Solving the original crime and bringing that knowledge to light will lift the curse, but only if the wrongdoer would suffer some kind of punishment for doing so. Applying the words literally can also end the curse: catching the wayward shadow in the midst of its misdeeds and casting bright light over it destroys the Shadow, and ends the curse.
The Atonement function of the {@spell Ceremony|xge|} spell can also end the curse, if it is cast by a follower of a deity of light or the sun.

entries.name: Non-player curses
entries: What happens when the target of a curse isn't a player? A curse can be a central element in a story. Perhaps the players are tasked with lifting a curse, or the villain of the story is the curse's victim. When not applied to players, you can take greater liberties with how the curse affects its victim. As written, a Rat Lord has no control over the rats that follow them, but you may wish a villainous Rat Lord to have such control. Or a non-player cursed with a Horrid Reflection frightens other people instead of themselves with their reflection. Such abilities could be too strong in the hands of creative players, and thus the curse fail to be a meaningful burden at all. But in the hands of the DM, can enhance the story. Many a curse in fiction comes with great power attached, but usually in such a way that the power isn't worth the price.

You can also use this to make a curse much more of a burden on a non-player character. Some of the mechanics of these curses as listed are meant to be fair on players, still allowing a player to enjoy the game while cursed, or to mitigate some of the curse's worst effects. NPCs under the control of the DM need no such mercy, and thus their curse might be more severe or more difficult to resolve.

entries.name: Glyphs of warding as traps
entries: An easy way of creating a magical trap is to use the {@spell Glyph of Warding} with the Spell Glyph function. This can be an actual Glyph of Warding spell, or other magic that functions in an identical manner, and makes sense in any dungeon that is guarded by a villain with access to spells of 3rd level or higher. But what spells to use? A simple damaging spell such as Fireball or Cloudkill is the most obvious choice, but there are endless creative options that let you use this kind of trap in interesting ways. Consider some of the following spells:

items: Entangle near enemies or other traps.
Grease at the top of a steep slope.
Thunderwave placed so enemies can hear the spell effect.
Enlarge/Reduce so that a creature can't fit out the door of the room it's in.
Gust of Wind near a cliff or trap.
Silence set so that it only triggers when someone attempts to cast a spell.
Polymorph in a situation that requires hands or speech.
Antilife Shell to block a passage guarded by constructs or undead.
Contagion near the beginning of a dungeon to weak intruders in advance.
Danse Macabre cast on guards that die near the glyph.
Modify Memory combined with Magic Mouth in a passage to create a false memory of finding a dead end.
Passwall to create pitfalls in solid floors or allow enemies to enter a room.
Flesh to Stone to trap intruders.
Reverse gravity to place pit traps on the ceiling, or cause them to trigger twice.
Earthquake to destroy a trapped structure with intruders inside.

data.name: Siege Equipment
entries: The Dungeon Master's Guide describes seven kinds of siege equipment, and mentions how some kinds of siege weapons can be loaded with different types of projectiles for different effects. This section describes five more kinds of siege equipment based on real historical or mythical devices, as well as a number of examples for alternative projectile types, including ones mentioned but not described in the DMG.

{@object Hwacha|MADMT}

entries.name: Additional Projectile Types
entries: {@b Ballista}

The large bolts of a ballista are easily attached to ropes or chains and fitted with barbed heads to create harpoons ideal for attaching to ships and larger creatures such as giants or whales, either to allow creatures to climb along the ropes or to pull the target closer.
In settings with gunpowder technology, ballista bolts can be fitted with fireworks that increase the range of the weapon and detonate shorty after being fired.
{@object Ballista (Firework)|MADMT}
{@object Ballista (Harpoon)|MADMT}
{@b Cannon}
The cast iron balls of a cannon are devestating testaments to the power of gunpowder, but technology also allows for more flexibility beyond these simple blunt projectiles.

Bundles of smaller projectiles, known as Grapeshot, are effective at close-range obliteration of crowds, while also being easier to improvise. An ill-equipped force can stuff a cannon with cutlery and pebbles when they run out of proper ammunition.
Two cannonballs connected by a chain whirl through the air and wrap around their targets, designed for shredding the sails and rigging of ships, they also work well against flying foes.
Fitting the propellant of the cannon into the projectile rather than into the barrel allows it to fire explosive  rockets with a shrapnel payload.
{@object Cannon (Chain Shot)|MADMT}
{@object Cannon (Grapeshot)|MADMT}
{@object Cannon (Rocket)|MADMT}
{@b Suspended Cauldron}
Acid is an effective alternative to boiling oil, especially against foes resistant to fire or when there are no facilities to heat the oil.

Grease isn't directly harmful to creatures it hits, but it leaves a slippery puddle behind that impedes anyone trying to charge past the defenders as they re-arm the cauldron, as well as being highly effective against foes trying to breach a fortified position by climbing ladders.

Icy cold water is very easy to source in certain climates, making it an economical choice of weapon. Against foes attacking in cold windy weather, it can quickly cause hypothermia, and leave a slippery hazard as it freezes on surfaces.

Though unlikely to cause serious harm, sewage is best used as a deterrent to demoralise a foe or to cause nausea that reduces the effectiveness of their assault. Often used as a desperation measure by besieged foes that have expended their more dangerous fluids.
{@object Suspended Cauldron (Acid)|MADMT}
{@object Suspended Cauldron (Grease)|MADMT}
{@object Suspended Cauldron (Ice Water)|MADMT}
{@object Suspended Cauldron (Sewage)|MADMT}
The Mangonel and Trebuchet both hurl the same kinds of projectiles via different methods, but their range and damage varies.

Hay soaked with oil can be set alight prior to firing. Igniting the hay takes place during the action used to load the weapon. Less effective at destroying fortifications than a simple stone except those made of wood.

Catapults make for an excellent delivery method for primative biological warfare. Baskets or hives full of stinging insects can quickly diminish enemy morale and cause disarray among the defenders, while festering corpses of humanoids or animals are a potent weapon of intimidation as well as a vector for disease that is especially effective during drawn-out sieges. Normally these diseases are represented by {@disease Sewer Plague} (described on page 257 of the DMG) but can be almost any sort of disease, including ones found in this document such as {@disease Boiling Blood|MADMT} or {@disease Blightpus|MADMT}.
Wheels or barrels embedded with blades can roll for a time after being hurled, they lack the impact of a boulder but are much better at slicing through tightly-packed infantry.
{@b Mangonel}
{@object Mangonel (Flaming Ball)|MADMT}

data.name: Bestiary
entries: There are countless ways of applying the contents of this document in your adventures. One way is to use them to inspire new monsters or as modifications to existing monsters. Sometimes a small twist is all you need to make a familiar foe feel fresh and exciting. Below are a few sample stat blocks to aid you. They are all creatures from the Monster Manual with one or two appropriate alterations. Bear in mind a couple of thing: First, that these are just examples to get you started and don't even begin to scratch the surface of how curses, diseases, hazards, traps, or poisons could be used in a campaign. Second, that non-player characters need not follow the same rules as player characters. Instead of following the rules written here to the letter, your focus should instead be on creating something that makes intuitive sense to the players, and is fun to engage with. For example, Contagious Troll Tumours only grants a very small amount of hitpoint regeneration to an infected player, since regeneration is a very powerful ability, but isn't meaningful when applied to a monster in a combat encounter. Instead, it makes more sense to give that monster regeneration more akin to that of a troll. It's more impactful and makes more sense to the players. Your players can't see the monster stat blocks, and likely won't notice as long as the mechanics remain somewhat consistent.
{@creature Awakened Shroud Vine Shrub|MADMT}

Shroud Vine bushes grow into eerie silhouettes of the creature that spawned them, but are otherwise normal bushes. Thus, they can be targeted by any magic that affects plants, such as the {@spell Awaken} spell.
{@creature Shroud Vine Druid|MADMT}

While Shroud Vine is an insidous blight to most people, some Druids see it as a means of connecting with nature, and form a symbiotic relationship with the parasite, and wield it as a weapon against their enemies.
{@creature Blightpus Kobold|MADMT}

Kobolds dwelling in the underdark are at great risk of Blightpus outbreaks due to their cramped lairs and communal living. Infected kobolds are likely to charge recklessly at threats, sacrificing themselves to use their infection against enemies of the tribe.
{@creature Tumourous Cave Bear|MADMT}

When wildlife or monsters ingest troll meat, they risk contracting Contagious Troll Tumours. While their increased resilience is a temporary boon that may lead to them dominating the local ecosystem and hedging out rivals, the disease will eventually overcome them, leading to the birth of a new troll.
{@creature Noble of the Horrid Reflection|MADMT}

Of the people likely to be cursed in this way, nobles are especially prime targets as they depend so heavily on their reputation, and the terror of having one's true nature revealed can eat away at them. Nonetheless, some villains aren't afraid of their wicked nature, but their foulness terrifies others, leaving them to fester in evil isolated from others.
{@creature Two-Faced Imp|MADMT}

As befitting their role as tempters and deceivers, devils are more likely than anyone to be cursed with two faces. Some come under this kind of curse as a result of clerics or divine entities that oppose fiends, other devils are cursed as punishment by their superiors.
{@creature Lodestone Elemental|MADMT}
Sometimes the forces that create  Lodestones can also give rise to elemental creatures. They are potent guardians of druidic temples, especially against foes that wield metal.
{@creature Shambling Mist Mound|MADMT}

Shambling mounds accumulate all kinds of plant matter as they devour their way through the wilderness. CMC normally stays static, feeding on the carrion its vapours kill, and ordinarily wouldn't fare well with mobility. However, a Shambling Mound generates enough carrion by itself that the fungus can easily survive.
{@creature 'False Dragon' aka Flamethrower Roc|MADMT}

Rocs, like crows, can learn how to use tools, so this flamethrower device is activated by a simple switch that the Roc can operate itself. The False Dragon is an attempt to create a flying artillery weapon with the might of a dragon, capable of devestating fly-by strafing runs, but one that also won't grow up to be an intelligent titan that can resent its captivity. Only two kinds of people would create a False Dragon: people know know all there is to know about Rocs, and people who know nothing about Rocs.
{@creature Fetid Hill Giant|MADMT}

Hill Giants are notoriously filthy, and have no dignity in battle. If you think you've caught a giant off-guard in the latrine, you're in for a revolting lesson. A hill giant has no shame in tossing the contents of its chamber pot at attackers, then clubbing the unfortunate creature with the pot, or hurling it at foes outside of the splash zone.
{@creature Venomous Assassin|MADMT}

Poison is an incredibly potent tool for assassination. Some assassins master the art of using poisons, and may pay tribute to gods of poison and death in order to learn their arts. Wyvern venom is common for its high toxicity, but some assassins use other mixtures. Quickbleed is useful against foes that may try to flee or take cover, as they can bleed to death even after leaving the assassin's sights. Assassins also know that they could suffer terrible fates if captured alive so carry cyanide pills to ensure they cannot be tortured, often concealed in a false tooth.

disease.name: Blightpus
entries: {@b Symptoms:} This fungal infection causes pustules filled with green or orange ooze to form across an afflicted creature's skin. When they burst, they eject a caustic acid onto anything nearby. These pustules are highly noticeable and extremely uncomfortable.

{@b Effects:} A diseased creature's skin is covered in a large quantity of acid-filled pustules. These pustules are volatile, and will burst if the diseased creature takes any bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage. When these pustules burst, each creature within 5ft must make a DC 12 Dexterity saving throw, taking 6 (2d6) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. The diseased creature automatically fails the save. This effect can't be triggered again for 1 hour while the infection is untreated, after which the acid pustules regrow.

{@b Contracting:} Blightpus is the parasitic form of a fungus known as Bursting Blightpuff (See the Dungeon & Wilderness Hazards section below). Bursting Blightpuff normally grows in damp underground environments, but can be found in other places, coating surfaces with volatile acidic bulbs of either orange or green. These fungal growths, or other infected creatures, can transmit the infection, since the fungal spores are transmitted by the acid. A creature subject to acid damage by either a patch of Bursting Blightpuff or the pustules of a creature infected with Blightpus must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw, becoming diseased on a failure. Once diseased, the creature begins to show symptoms and become contagious after 1 hour. A creature resistant to acid is immune to contracting this disease.
{@b Diagnosis:} Its easy to tell at first sight that there's something very wrong with someone infected by Blightpus. However, you can roll an ability check to find out more.
Wisdom (Medicine) 9 or lower – Its hard to tell anything conclusively about this infection.
Wisdom (Medicine) 10 to 14 – This appears to be a fungal infection of some sort.

Wisdom (Medicine) 15 or higher – You known the name of this disease, and that the acid is the source of the contagion. You also know how to drain the pustules to prevent further contagion, and that a cured creature can still be contagious if they have fully developed pustules.
Intelligence (Nature) or Wisdom (Survival) 15 or higher – You know about Bursting Blightpuff, where it grows and how it transmits this disease.

{@b Treatment:} Any effect that cures disease instantly cures a creature, but does not destroy any pustules that have grown, simply prevents new ones from growing. These pustules bursting can still be contagious, even potentially re-infecting a cured creature.

Acid pustules can be carefully drained to prevent them from exploding violently. The infected creature or another creature within 5ft can spend 10 minutes using a suitable sharp instrument to make a DC 13 Dexterity (Medicine) check. On a success, all pustules across the infected creature's body are drained thus cannot burst, and grow back in 1 hour. On a failure, the pustules burst as normal as if the infected creature took damage.

disease.name: Boiling Blood
entries: {@b Symptoms:} In early stages of the infection, an afflicted creature suffers from fever, restlessness, and profuse sweating, easily mistaken for other kinds of disease. Later stages of the infection involve the afflicted's skin being raw pink, and steam pouring out of the mouth, nose, and tear ducts. When injured, their blood visible sizzles and steams. Creatures killed by this disease seem to boil from the inside out, and continue to be unusually hot even after death, with some giving off the scent of cooked meat. Almost any activity that causes a victim's heart rate to accelerate is painful as their body courses with unbearable heat.

{@b Effects:} The disease has no effect until 8 hours after a creature is infected, after which the creature suffers the effects of the first stage of the disease. 24 hours after being infected, it suffers the effects of the second stage of the disease in addition to the effects of the first stage.

Once 8 hours have passed, the afflicted creature becomes feverish. It has disadvantage on all ability checks, and struggles to rest. At the end of a short or long rest the afflicted creature must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature only gains half as many hitpoints as they normally would from a rest. In addition, the creature cannot sleep by normal means, and gains none of the benefits of sleeping.

Once 24 hours have passed, the creature starts to leak steam out of their facial orifices. The fever intensifies, and the creature has disadvantage on all ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws. The creature can't sleep or gain any benefits from resting at all. Each time it exerts itself significantly or engages in some kind of physically strenous activity (such as taking the Dash action, making a weapon attack roll, or attempts to lift or drag more than their carrying capacity) it must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 1d4+1 fire damage.
A creature imune to fire damage is also immune to all effects of Boiling Blood. A creature that has resistance to fire damage has advantage on all saving throws caused by this disease.

{@b Contracting:} Boiling Blood is primarily transmitted through sweat, but can also be transmitted through other bodily fluids such as blood and saliva, so is usually only a threat to those in close contact with the infected such as family or medical proffessionals, or people who handle the clothes or bathwater of the infected.
Corpses of the infected also remain contagious for 48 hours after death. It's easy to tell when a body is contagious as fluids bubble and spit, steam rises from the corpse, and it does not cool.

Animals infected with this pathogen seek out water to cool themselves, thus potentially infecting still water, and their exhaustion in addition to constantly staying out in the open makes them easy prey. As such, eating infected animals is the most common origin of Boiling Blood outbreaks in humanoid settlements. Adventurers are more likely to contract Boiling Blood from fire-immune monsters that unknowingly carry the disease, such as red dragons and salamanders.
Cooking meat of an infected animal does not kill Boiling Blood as it might do for other kinds of bacteria. Similarly, using hot water to wash one's hands is ineffective.

A creature coming into contact with an infected creature or their bodily fluids must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw, becoming infected on a failed save. The Boiling Blood pathogen cannot tolerate cold temperatures, so in extremely cold environments a creature has advantage on this save.

{@b Diagnosis:} The early stage of this disease can sometimes be difficult to differentiate from other kinds of illness that cause fever, easily leading to misdiagnosis, but the later stage of the disease is unique and easy to recognise by anyone who has heard of Boiling Blood.
Wisdom (Medicine) 13 or lower, first stage - Misdiagnosis. It appears to be a fairly common fever that isn't life-threatening, the patient might recover after some rest and proper hydration.
Wisdom (Medicine) 14 to 20, first stage - The rapid onset of this fever and high temperature is concerning, and is likely to develop further. The afflicted creature needs urgent medical attention.

Wisdom (Medicine) 21 or higher, first stage - The speed and intensity of this fever means it's most likely to be Boiling Blood. You know roughly how long the disease takes to progress to the next stage, and how to treat it.
Wisdom (Medicine) 5 or lower, second stage - Misdiagnosis. Maybe the creature swallowed some kind of combustible chemical.
Wisdom (Medicine) 6 to 13, second stage - This appears to be Boiling Blood. You know the disease is deadly but aren't sure how best to treat it.
Wisdom (Medicine) 14 or higher - This appears to be Boiling Blood. You know that cold temperatures are the best way to treat this disease, and you know it is usually contracted through sweat.

{@b Treatment:} The bacteria that causes this disease is unusually resilient, and resists disease-curing magic. An infected creature targeted by a magical effect that cures disease must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a success, the disease is cured. On a failed save, the magic has no effect.

This disease easily survives heat from cooking or hot water, but cannot tolerate cold temperatures. Thus, icy cold water is best for washing one's hands, and freezing food for 8 hours destroys any Boiling Blood bacteria within it.

A bath of icy water suppresses all effects of this disease. For each hour it spends submerged in icy water, or whenever it makes a saving throw against {@hazard Extreme Cold} or {@hazard Frigid Water} (DMG page 110), it can make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a success, the disease ends.
Short bursts of cold damage as might be inflicted by magic or a white dragon's breath weapon don't affect this disease, only prolonged full-body cooling will be of any aid.

This disease prevents a creature from sleeping naturally. Magic induced sleep, such as might be caused by the _Sleep_ spell, still works. Alternatively, a creature may be made unconscious by poisons such as Oil of Taggit, and gain the benefits of sleep.
The Player's Handbook notes that a creature fully immersed in water has resistance to fire damage. This applies in the case of Boiling Blood too, granting advantage on saving throws against it.

disease.name: Cannibal Craving
entries: {@b Symptoms:} Afflicted creatures feel a compulsion to eat the meat of other humanoids, and vomit up other food unless supplemented with human meat. Madness is often associated with this disease, but isn't an actual symptom of the pathogen, but a result of the mental stress of eating other people or being unable to eat. In animals, they turn more aggressive once they realise they can only eat humanoid meat.

{@b Effects:} Whenever the afflicted creature eats, at least half of its meal must include flesh from a humanoid. If not, it immediately regurgitates its meal and gains no nutritional benefit from eating. Neither can it imbibe potions unless the potion is mixed with blood or flesh of a humanoid. A creature is not aware of the nature of its infection, but does start to perceive humanoid blood or flesh as being more appealing, suddenly finding the scent alluring or salivating over dead or wounded individuals.

{@b Contracting:} The main ways of contracting the disease are through being bitten by an infected individual, or eating them. However, the disease can also linger in water sources contaminated by bodies of those infected, and is also know to be incredibly cold-resistant, surviving frozen in ice or still cold water.

In populations of humanoids where cannibalism has been practiced across multiple generation, such as certain tribes of lizardfolk or kobolds, the individuals may be immune to its effects but can still carry and transmit the disease, so conflict with these races can cause outbreaks, however most infections usually come about from wild animal attacks where small populations of predators becomes unusually aggressive and attack humans unprovoked in order to feed. Gnolls are also a know carrier of this disease, they aren't immune but they still seldom notice if they have it.

A humanoid or beast that consumes the flesh of an infected creature or contaminated water, or is bitten by an infected creature, must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw against disease, becoming infected on a failure.

{@b Diagnosis:} the disease is exceptionally hard to diagnose without seeing its full effects, and most people would reasonably conclude that an infected person can't eat any food at all before considering that human meat alone will stay down. Thus, someone who hasn't had the opportunity to observe the full effects of the disease can easily misdiagnose it.
Wisdom (Medicine) 10 or lower – Misdiagnosis. It's a simple stomach bug. It will pass as long as you stay hydrated.
Wisdom (Medicine) 15 or lower – This is a serious disease that requires immediate action. But you can't diagnose it.
Wisdom (Medicine) 16 or higher – You believe the afflicted individual is host to a pathogen that is rejecting most food, but you don't know what food the pathogen would accept.
Wisdom (Medicine) 10 or lower, and cannibalism has been seen to prevent vomiting – Misdiagnosis. The afflicted patient is clearly a depraved madman.

Wisdom (Medicine) 11 or higher, and cannibalism has been seen to prevent vomiting  – Whatever infection the creature suffers from seeks only humanoid flesh. Mixing some with their food should allow them to eat.

Wisdom (Medicine) 17 or higher, and cannibalism has been seen to prevent vomiting – Once normal remedies have been shown to fail, you also realise that the disease needs to be weakened by some sort of toxin.

Wisdom (Survival) 8 to 11, and cannibalism has been seen to prevent vomiting – You've heard of Cannibal Craving occurring in starving frontier settlements and the like, but you're not sure if it's a real disease or a strange delusion that afflicts starving people forced into cannibalism.
Wisdom (Survival) 12 or higher, and cannibalism has been seen to prevent vomiting – You know that Cannibal Craving is usually the result of infected meat or water, or bites from wild animals.

{@b Treatment:} The disease is unusually hardy to disease-curing magic, perhaps as a result of living endemically in humanoid populations in ancient times. Most attempts to cure the disease using magic will just produce stomach pains. The disease has natural defences against both medicine and magic that would destroy it. The disease must first be weakened with poison. The poison must be mixed with humanoid flesh or blood to ensure that pathogen doesn't reject it, and then the poison must be consumed in order to flush it through the infected creature's digestive system. Once this has been done, magic or medicine will work as normal.

disease.name: Contagious Troll Tumours
entries: {@b Symptoms:} The afflicted creature gains a mild form of a troll's regeneration powers, but injuries form dangerous tumours of troll flesh as they heal, usually appearing as green lumps which can form both internally and externally. While they don't impede the afflicted in any way, they are extremely painful and uncomfortable. In extreme cases, missing limbs regenerate to become troll-like or the afflicted grows small vestigial appendages. Worse still, these embedded growths of troll flesh can regenerate into an entire troll if the growths kill the afflicted.

{@b Effects:} The afflicted creature regenerates 1 hitpoint at the start of each of its turns, unless it has taken acid or fire damage since the start of its previous turn. If it's missing any body parts, they regrow when the creature finishes a long rest. An afflicted creature doesn't die or make death saving throws unless it cannot regenerate at the start of its turn, although it can still die normally by failing three death saves or through taking massive damage. For every 10 hitpoints the afflicted creature regenerates, or for each missing body part it regrows, the afflicted creature must make a Constitution saving throw. On a failed saved, one green tumour of troll flesh forms on its body. The DC of the save equals 10 plus the number of tumours on the creature's body. If the DC of the saving throw reaches 20, and the creature fails that saving throw, it dies, and the tumours immediately grow into a Troll which appears in the dead creature's space. The afflicted creature automatically gains one tumour for every 24 hours that passes.

{@b Contracting:} Contagious Troll Tumours really stretch the definition of disease. Trolls can regenerate from almost any injury given time, but can be slain. In the process of battling a troll, it and its foe invariably end up covered in each other's blood. This usually isn't an issue, but if tiny parts of the troll's being end up lodged in an open wound, they can adhere themselves as they try to regenerate. Even after the troll dies, these pieces of flesh survive thanks to grafting themselves into the host's circulatory system. This is the start of a troll tumour. Like a cancer, it grows uncontrollably within the host yet is rooted into its basic bodily functions, kept alive by the thing it is killing. Troll flesh regenerates and mutates much quicker than any mundane cancer, quickly overwhelming any immune response. As it grows, small parts of the tumour can break off and seed themselves in other parts of the body, forming new tumours.

Usually only a heavily wounded troll whose regeneration is struggling to keep it alive or whose dismembered limbs are flailing about on their own can inflict CTT, and the only people at risk are those who have open wounds from the troll's attacks and are also attacking it with piercing or slashing damage from within 5ft. Anything that prevents a troll from regenerating also prevents it from spreading CTT. A less common way of contracting it is to eat a troll. Stomach acid usually deals with any potential tumours, but eating enough troll can still cause a tumour especially if one has cuts, bruises, or sores inside the mouth. When a troll dies, the DM determines which if any of the creatures that participated in the fight could have come into contact with troll gore while having open wounds.
Each affected creature must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw, becoming afflicted with CTT on a failed save.

{@b Diagnosis:} Green troll flesh growths are easy to spot when they grow externally, but the usual giveaway for this affliction is the enhanced regeneration. Diagnosing the condition is tricky, but trickier still is knowing how to operate on the tumours without them simply growing back. People knowledgeable on giants are more likely to be able to accurately diagnose CTT. A creature that speaks Giant or otherwise has knowledge on giants and their history has advantage on ability checks made to diagnose CTT.
Wisdom (Medicine) 5 or lower - Misdiagnosis. You have cool regeneration powers now. This can only be good for your health.
Wisdom (Medicine) 10 or lower - These growths are out of control and need to be treated, but they heal so fast that you're not sure how to handle it.

Wisdom (Medicine) 11 to 15 - You're not sure what caused these growths, but it seems that they get worse the more the afflicted regenerates from wounds. Using other forms of healing to close wounds before they can regenerate should slow down tumour growth.

Wisdom (Medicine)16 or higher - You've heard of Contagious Troll Tumours, and know this to be caused by small fragments of troll flesh getting into open wounds. You know these tumours can eventually regenerate into a full troll. You believe that physically cutting out the growths is the best course of action, which is best done on a sedated patient.

Intelligence (History) 12 to 16 - You've heard of trolls and their infamous ability to regenerate from almost any injury unless burned with acid or fire. These lumps of green flesh that heal extremely quickly reminds you of trolls.

Intelligence (History) 17 or higher - You know a fair bit about trolls and the most extreme forms their regeneration can take, that even scraps of flesh can regrow into a full troll and that trolls sometimes graft the flesh of other creatures onto their own.

{@b Treatment:} Trolls are extremely resilient even without their innate regeneration powers. CTT is no different. Tiny slivers of troll flesh inside the victim can be destroyed like almost any parasite, with magic that cures disease, but this will fail if any tumours have developed. The large tumours need to be surgically removed as they're too resilient to be magically cured. Removing a tumour requires a fine sharp instrument, and for the surgeon to make a Dexterity (Medicine) check. The surgeon can choose to only remove a selected number of tumours, which they may choose to do on fragile patients who might not easily survive a longer more invasive surgery. The DC of the check equals 10 plus the number of tumours the surgeon is attempting to remove. The surgery takes 5 minutes for each tumour the surgeon attempts to remove. On a success, the tumours are removed. If the total roll was less than 10, no tumours are removed. Otherwise, a partial success is achieved, and only some tumours are removed, an amount equal to the total of the medicine check minus 10. For each tumour removed, the patient takes 1 point of slashing damage. For each tumour the surgeon attempted to remove but failed, the patient takes 1+1d4 slashing damage. A removed tumour regrows unless the site of the tumour is immediately treated with acid or fire, enough to cause at least 1 point of damage.

Unless the patient is incapacitated during the surgery, they are at risk of flinching. For each tumour removed while the patient is not incapacitated, the patient must make a Constitution saving throw. The DC for this save is 10 for a successfully removed tumour, 15 for a failed tumour removal. On a failed save, the patient flinches, and takes an additional 2d4 slashing damage from the tumour removal.

Once a tumour is removed, it can still attempt to regenerate, although it is extremely weak. Unless the tumour is destroyed with fire or acid, roll a d10. On a 10, the tumour grows into a troll after 24 hours. Otherwise, it dies.

disease.name: Earwyrms
entries: {@b Symptoms:} Earwyrms are tiny wingless draconic creatures that reside in the ear canal of other creatures. They numb the flesh around them so their presence isn't felt, using poison stinger like those of pseudodragons, but they have a habit of mimicking sounds they hear, especially music, their relatively quiet voices being quite loud enough when their heads are resting on one's eardrum. Earwyrms are harmless, but incredibly annoying. Their compulsive music mimicry can inhibit a creature's ability to hear things properly or sleep, which is especially distracting for spellcasters, and getting them excited or riled can provoke them into singing so loudly that their host cannot hear anything at all. Earwyrms sneak out of their host's ear when they sleep once every three days to search for food.

{@b Effects:} Earwyrms have no stat block. They have a +0 bonus to all rolls, and have the Dragon type. While inhabiting another creature's ear canal, the Earwyrm has full cover against any effects originating from outside the host creature.

A creature infected by an Earwyrm cannot percieve the Earwyrm while it is not making noise. The DM determines the Earwyrm's behaviour, which is erratic. The Earwyrm will repeat sounds it has heard, usually music, but also animal sounds or speech, and will continue to do so while it is awake. The earwyrm sleeps for 6 hours a day. While the earwyrm is awake, an infected creature has disadvantage on all Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing. If the Earwyrm chooses, it can generate noise loud enough to deafen its host.
The Earwyrm is not normally dangerous, but is has a few ways of defending itself if a creature tries to remove it from its host.

An Earwyrm doesn't wish harm to its host, but will retaliate if threatened with direct violence. It can emit a loud screech that deal 1 thunder damage to its host. It can deal this damage no more than once in a round.
If its host is concentrating on a spell, the Earwyrm can unleash a distracting string of noise that forces the host to make a Concentration check with a DC of 10.

Earwyrms aren't very intelligent but do understand that it is in their best interest to keep their host alive. Thus, Earwyrms will interfere on occasion whether their help is wanted or not, in the limited capacity as they are able. A Earwyrm will wake its host if they are sleeping and the Earwyrm percieves danger. They will intentionally deafen their host if the host is charmed by another creature, so that they can't hear any commands and thus cannot obey them. They will also use their screech to deal damage if the host is under the influence of magic such as the {@spell Sleep} or {@spell Dominate Person} spells where the target of the spell can repeat the save or end the effect if it takes damage.
If an Earwyrm inhabits a single host for 10 days, it lays an egg, and leaves its current host to find a new one. The egg hatches into an Earwyrm after another 10 days.

{@b Contracting:} Earwyrms live in all kinds if environments, where they prowl for sleeping prey. When they encounter a sleeping creature, the Earwyrm makes a Dexterity (Stealth) check against the target's Passive Perception score. On a failed check, the creature notices something crawling on them, which feels similar to a large insect, and deters the Earwyrm. On a successful stealth check, the sleeping creature remians unaware and is infected by the Earwyrm. An Earwyrm that leaves its host to feed doesn't need to make this check again when it returns, as it uses its venom stinger to numb its host's sense of touch enough that the light tread of an Earwyrm can't be detected.

Some creatures are known to breed and train Earwyrms for domestic purposes, and intentionally allow themselves to become hosts. They are usually trained to mimic specific music the trainer wants them to repeat. More rarely, they're used for espionage, to act as hidden recording devices, and creatures that frequently come into conflict with mind-controlling creatures such as Illithids keep Earwyrms as rudimentary anti-charm measures. In these cases, the Earwyrms are likely to escape once they're out in the field unless fed frequently.

{@b Diagnosis:} Despite being a relatively rare affliction, it's not hard to diagnose. Most intelligent creatures will choose to simply inspect an afflicted creature's ear canal, and might snatch a glimpse of the Earwyrm. Creatures knowledgeable on dragon type creatures can also know of Earwyrms. They might also roll to see if they know more.
Wisdom (Medicine) 10 to 14 - This is a case of Earwyrms. It's a tiny draconic creature that lives in your ear.
Wisdom (Medicine) 15 or higher - This is an Earwyrm. They're not dangerous, just really annoying. It's best to wait until it leaves of its own accord to feed.

Intelligence (Arcana or History) 15 or higher - This is an Earwyrm, a distant relation to Pseudodragons. It has to leave its host to feed, and eats tiny insects such as mosquitos and aphids. They understand the Draconic language.
{@b Treatment:} Despite being technically parasites, Earwyrms can't be treated with normal disease-curing magic.

A creature that is targeted by poison-curing magic, or who is immune to poison, is healed of the numbing poison of the Earwyrm. A creature cured this way can percieve the Earwyrm inside their ear canal or when the Earwyrm leaves their body. The Earwyrm must make a new Dexterity (Stealth) check if it leaves.

Earwyrms are difficult to remove by force without hurting the host, as they can dig their claws into the surrounding flesh. An Earwyrm must be Incapacitated, such as by the {@spell Sleep} or {@spell Hold Monster} spell before it can be removed.

Earwyrms cannot speak but understand Draconic. An Earwyrm can be convinced to leave its host temporarily if a creature that speaks Draconic makes a DC 15 Charisma (Persuasion) check, and has some form of food to use as a lure.

Earwyrms occasionally have to leave their host of their own accord, but won't do so unless it is sure it isn't being observed. Blocking the ears to prevent it's return to its host, forces the Earwyrm to leave to find another host.

disease.name: Glass Transmorgification
entries: {@b Symptoms:} Part of the afflicted creature's body is transformed into some sort of brittle substance, usually glass. Most commonly this occurs in the bones or other internal structure. People with this condition are usually innately aware of their condition even if there are no outward signs of being affected.

{@b Effects:} A creature afflicted by Glass Transmogrification has a vulnerability to Bludgeoning damage. The condition has other effects determined by which part of the body is transformed. The DM decides which part of the body is transformed, or rolls randomly to determine it. These effects apply immediately after the afflicted creature takes Bludgeoning damage, and lasts until it regains hitpoints by any means.

{@b Contracting:} Although incredibly rare, this condition is usually the result of a faulty or expired potion, the like of which are all too common on the black market. Potions known to cause Glass Transmogrification are mostly those involving transmutation magic, such as a potion of Growth or Resistance. A creature that drinks a faulty potion must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw after the effects of the potion end. On a failed save, the effects of Glass Transmogrification appear after 3d6 hours. The creature becomes aware of this effect once it appears.

rows: The creature's has disadvantage on all ability checks or attack rolls that involve the use of the affected arm or hand, and cannot use the affected arm to perform the somatic components of spells.
The creature's speed is halved and it cannot dash unless it can move without the use of its legs.
The creature has disadvantage on Constitution saving throws and ability checks.

entries: {@b Diagnosis:} If you're looking for it, its not hard to diagnose, especially when the patient more often than not has an uncanny sense of what's wrong with them. This simple process is vastly complicated by the existence of the comparatively much more common Glass Delusion, itself still a rare condition. A creature can attempt an ability check to gain more information:

Wisdom (Medicince) 10 or lower – You misdiagnose the condition as Glass Delusion. You gain the same information as rolling a 10 to make a diagnosis on Glass Delusion. If you see someone suffer from the effects of Glass Transmogrification after taking Bludgeoning damage, you automatically know you made a misdiagnosis.
Wisdom (Medicine) 11 to 14 – You realise the afflicted creature is partly made of glass.
Wisdom (Medicine) 15 or higher – You believe this partial transformation to be an unintended side effect of some sort of transmutation magic that can't be cured with ordinary disease-curing effects.

Intelligence (Arcana) 15 or higher – If the condition has been properly diagnosed, you know that magic that could restore flesh from inanimate material, or that regenerates body parts of all kinds might be an effective cure.

{@b Treatment:} Treating Glass Transmogrification isn't straightforward, but much easier than Glass Delusion. Any magic that cures petrification or that restores missing body parts will work. Any effect that gives the afflicted creature a resistance to Bludgeoning damage suppresses all negative effects of the condition for as long as the resistance lasts, but does not cure the creature.

disease.name: Glass Delusion
entries: {@b Symptoms:} A creature suffering from Glass Delusion believes themselves to be partially or wholly made of some brittle substance, most commonly glass but sometimes other substances like earthenware or ice. Usually the afflicted creature believes their bones or a single limb to be affected, but full-body delusions rarely occur. This belief persists even in the face of objective evidence to the contrary. Typically a delusional creature becomes paranoid that the affected body part is now exceptionally fragile and takes great measures to protect it from damage, such as wearing incredibly thick padded clothing, restraining the relevant area in a cast, or even refusing to leave a safe place. A less common symptom is the target believing themselves to be transparent and somehow that any lies or secrets are now laid bare for all to see. Most cases of Glass Delusion escalate into extreme paranoia, as the afflicted creature is hounded on all sides by people telling it something it "knows" not to be true, which can often make them difficult to approach for treatment.

{@b Effects:} The precise effects of Glass Delusion vary depending on what part of the body is the focus of the delusion. If a creature contracts Glass Delusion, the DM can choose any number of the options below, or roll to determine the effect randomly. Each form of the delusion also has a severe version with harsher effects. For every 10 days that the delusion isn't treated, the DM chooses to either add another focus area for the delusion, or for a severe version of the delusion to manifest in an already affected body part.

{@b Contracting:} Glass Delusion sometimes occurs after a creature drinks a faulty potion. Black market love potions are notorious for this, but other potions that involve transmutation or mind-altering magic are also known culprits. Wicked creatures such as hags sometimes intentionally create draughts that induce this effect and use it to torment their foes. A creature that drinks a faulty potion must succeed on a DC 10 Wisdom saving throw after the potion's effects end. The effects of the delusion start to appear after 3d6 hours.

{@b Diagnosis:} Glass Delusion appears often in folk tales and historical anecdotes, and its symptoms are quite obvious, so its seldom rare for the condition to go unnoticed or undiagnosed even by those not learned in medicine. While its clear to any person interacting with a delusional patient that the afflicted believes themselves to be made of glass, they may roll an ability check to gain further insight:

Wisdom (Medicine) 5 or lower – You believe the patient really is made of glass. Unless the creature making this check also suffers from Glass Delusion, any amount of practical examination or testing can prove this conclusion wrong.
Wisdom (Medicine) 6 to 10 – You know the name of this phenomenon, and that it is a strange delusion that is somewhat magical in origin.
Wisdom (Medicine) 11 to 16 – You know this powerful delusion can't be treated by simply proving that the victim isn't made of glass, the disorder is more complicated than that.
Wisdom (Medicine) 17 or higher – This delusion affects the mind, so the cure has to as well.
Wisdom (Insight) 13 or higher - You understand some of the afflicted creature's point of view and know it to be irrational, thus simple proof of the truth won't work.

{@b Treatment:} The key to treating Glass Delusion is in the mind. Magic that heals diseases doesn't work, although magic that cures indefinite madness does. Other mind-altering magics can also be used to improvise a cure, such as most charm effects. The best method is to use magic to charm someone into thinking they've been cured or that something you are offering them is an effective remedy. For example, using Charm Person to get a deluded patient to trust you and take the medicine or spell you offer them, or using Modify Memory to implant a false memory of being cured. This magically empowered placebo is a good remedy for a magic-caused delusion, but requires a bit of improvisation and creativity. If the affected creature learns afterwards that they were charmed, they remain cured.

rows: The afflicted creature refuses to use the affected arm for any strenuous activity, such as shoving or grappling, attacking with a weapon, holding a shield, or heavy lifting, but can still use that arm or hand normally. Any ability check that requires the use of the affected arm or hand is made at disadvantage.

The creature refuses to use the affected limb for anything that isn't completely essential to survival (e.g. eating food if they have no other means of doing so, climbing a ladder away from a deadly enemy). This includes refusing to perform the somatic components of spells.
The afflicted creature's walking speed is reduced by 5ft and it refuses to dash unless not doing so would result in its death, and it refuses to carry more than half its total carrying capacity.

The afflicted creature refuses to use that leg or foot for any movement at all. Its walking speed is halved if only one leg is affected, if both legs are affected then it may only move by crawling or by using another mode of movement such as flying or swimming.

The afflicted creature refuses to wear anything except the most protective set of armour available to it, and will not doff the armour except to don a different set of armour. It will ignore its armour proficiencies in this instance. It will also refuse to move through another creature's space or squeeze into a smaller space.
The afflicted creature becomes Frightened whenever it take bludgeoning damage. This can include being Frightened by abstract concepts such as heights or inanimate objects.
The afflicted creature believes that other creatures can see through it and that it casts no shadow, even if it can still see itself. It has disadvantage on all Charisma (Deception) checks.
The creature cannot lie at all, and will reveal any lies or secrets upon prompting.

disease.name: Shroud Vine
entries: {@b Symptoms:} A web of thorny vines grows across the skin of the afflicted creature, with spiked roots embedded into its flesh. As the condition worsens, the afflicted creature's behaviour becomes more erratic as it talks to plants and seeks out sunlight.

{@b Effects:} A Shroud Vine infection progresses through multiple stages of severity each day that the infection persists. Originating from the point of infection, vines start to grow over the victim until most of the victim's body is covered, at which point the infection is lethal.

Stage 0: For the first 24 hours after contracting the disease, the afflicted creature shows no clear signs of being diseased. The only signifier of being infected appears one hour after contracting the disease, that being a slight discolouration and inflammation at the point of infection. There's no effects during this stage.

Stage 1: First vine growth appears after 24 hours. Attempting to remove the growth causes 6 (2d6) piercing damage to the afflicted creature, and the vines regrow within 2 hours. This damage increases by 6 (2d6) for each stage of the disease.

Stage 2: After 48 hours, the vine growth becomes larger. The afflicted creature can use the thorns to bolster its unarmed strikes using a covered part of its body. These thorns count as a natural weapon, dealing piercing damage equal to 1d4 + the creature's strength modifier. The vine begins to sap the vitality of its host. The creature requires twice the normal amount of food and water, and must spend at least 1 hour in direct sunlight each day to be considered properly nourished.

Stage 3: After 72 hours, the vine growth covers roughly a quarter of the afflicted creature's body. The afflicted creature gains the ability to speak with and understand Plant type creatures within 10ft of it as if they shared a language. Additionally, if the Plant has an intelligence score of 5 or lower, it is nonhostile to the afflicted creature and will ignore it unless provoked. Whenever the afflicted creature regains hitpoints and is not in direct sunlight, the amount of hitpoints it regains is halved (minimum of 1 hitpoint).

Stage 4: After 96 hours, the vine growth covers over half of the afflicted creature's body. The creature gains the ability to communicate simple ideas with nonmagical plants, such as significant events from the last day, any active threats in the area, or whether a plant is toxic. The creature gains no special ability to influence plants in this way. In addition, the creature can cause the vine growth to grow over armour it is wearing when it finishes a short rest in direct sunlight. The piercing damage of its thorns increases by 1d4, and its armour class can't be less than 13. The afflicted creature also has advantage on ability checks to hide in or around foliage. The thorns on its body are now contagious and capable of transmitting Shroud Vine to other creatures.

Stage 5: After 120 hours, the disease finally begins to kill the afflicted creature. Once stage 5 is reached, the target's hitpoint maximum is reduced by an amount equal to the maximum value of its hit die every hour. When the creature's hitpoint maximum is reduced to zero, it dies.

The creature instinctively knows that it is dying, and feels a strange compulsion to rest in areas of direct sunlight. If the creature is in an area of direct sunlight, it refuses to leave that area unless compelled by magic. Once the creature dies, a Shroud Vine bush sprouts from its body after 24 hours in the approximate size and shape of the dead creature.

{@b Contracting:} The only ways to contract Shroud Vine are either through contact with a Shroud Vine bush or a creature in the late stages (Stage 4 or 5) of an infection. In either case, even a light scratch of the thorns can induce infection, with such a superficial injury being easily overlooked until visible symptoms set in. In the case of bushes, since they grow over the corpses of other victims, looters are often scratched when drawn to the belongings of the dead. Shroud Vine bushes appear in rough silhouettes of the creatures they killed, forming eerie shadows or humanoids and beasts. These bushes occur in the forests on the material plane in all biomes but are rare except where cultivated by especially isolated druids, in the feywild where they can form small groves and are weaponised by hags, and even in the Abyss, most notably Demogorgon's realm of the Gaping Maw. A creature scratched by a Shroud Vine must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw, becoming infected on a failure. A creature that succeeds on this save is immune for the next 24 hours.
{@b Diagnosis:} Shroud Vine is a very obscure infection, but is known well in frontier campfire stories of man-shaped bushes, and by wilderness-dwelling folk such as druids and hags.
Wisdom (Medicine)5 or lower – Misdiagnosis. You can't see anything wrong with this, in fact it could be beneficial.
Wisdom (Medicine) 13 or lower – You don't know anything about this infection.
Wisdom (Medicine) 14 to 17 – Its some sort of parasitic vine. You understand that removing the exterior growths alone isn't enough, and that its probably feeding on the victim.
Wisdom (Medicine) 18 or higher – You've heard of Shroud Vine, and know that it is transmitted through the thorns.
