Intelligence (Nature) 15 or higher – You know this infection is caused by Shroud Vine, and you know that it grows in creature-shaped bushes that grow over the bodies of those who die to the infection.

Wisdom (Survival) 15 or higher – You've heard of Shroud Vine, and know its transmitted through the thorns and is usually lethal. You also know that people with the parasite go mad, talking to plants and seek to lie in sunlight, and that tearing the growths off does more harm than good.

{@b Treatment:} Shroud Vine has a two-stage treatment. First, the exterior vines need to be removed. This process pulls at roots in the skin, which can seriously harm an afflicted creature, but treatment is ineffective without this first step. Once the vines are removed, ordinary disease-curing magic will instantly cure the affliction.

Attempting to cure the disease without removing the vines simply slows its growth, preventing progress to the next stage for 24 hours, and this technique is used by people who want to reap certain benefits from the disease such as the ability to talk to plants. If a creature's Shroud Vine infection is prevented from progressing for 30 days, it becomes symbiotic, and doesn't progress any further.

Anyone trying to experiment with magic to cure Shroud Vine ought to be careful. Targeting an afflicted creature with magic that increases plant growth instantly causes the infection to progress one stage.

hazard.name: Bloomers
entries: A peculiar mushroom capable of inflating itself to ward off predators. Its typical resting state resembles a cluster of dirty white spheres on a white stalk. Sprouting in all kinds of environments, Bloomers aren't especially dangerous by themselves, their sudden and startling inflation being more than enough to deter most ordinary threats, unless they happen to grow near cliffs where they can push people off.

Normally the mushroom occupies a 5ft cube. When a creature moves within 5ft of the Bloomer, it rapidly inflates to occupy a 15ft cube. Creatures are pushed into the nearest unoccupied space, unless there are no available spaces, in which case it remains where it is and is {@condition restrained} under the bulk of fungal balloons. If the Bloomer dies it rapidly but harmlessly deflates, but if it takes slashing or piercing damage it bursts in a powerful blast or air. Creatures within 5ft of the Bloomer must make a DC 10 Strength saving throw or be pushed 5ft away from the Bloomer and be knocked {@condition prone}. A Bloomer has an AC of 7, 5 hitpoints, is resistant to bludgeoning damage, and immune to psychic damage. Identifying a Bloomer requires a DC 10 Intelligence (Nature) or Wisdom (Survival) check.

hazard.name: Bursting Blightpuff
entries: A fungus that grows in slimy webs on rock or earthen surfaces in damp environments and is covered in fragile bulbs filled with brightly coloured acid. It can also infect living creatures (see {@disease Blightpus|MADMT} in the Disease section above). These bulbs are very fragile and burst on contact, spraying anything nearby with acid and Blightpuff spores. There are two varieties of Bursting Blightpuff, distinguished mainly by the colour of their acid bulbs, orange and green. Orange Blightpuff can be found deep underground, so Blightpus infections run rampant in communities of certain underdark creatures like troglodytes and gricks, and Myconids also cultivate it as a deterrent against intruders around their territory. Green Blightpuff is much rarer, and grows in wet forests and swamps, thriving in the territory of black dragons. A patch of Blightpuff covers at least a 10ft square area but can often be much larger.
If the patch is disturbed, such as by taking damage or a creature moves into its area, then bulbs across its surface erupt. A patch can erupt multiple times in a turn.

Each creature within 10ft of the source of the disturbance must make a DC 10 Dexterity saving throw, taking 7 (2d6) acid damage on a failure. A creature that fails this save has to make an additional DC 10 Constitution saving throw against disease or be infected with Blightpus. A creature moving into the area or starting its turn there can choose to move at half speed and make a DC 15 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check. On a success, its movement doesn't trigger Blightpuff eruptions for the rest of its turn.

A 5ft square patch of Bursting Blightpuff has an AC of 5 and 5 hitpoints, and is immune to acid and psychic damage. Identifying Bursting Blightpuff requires DC 15 Intelligence (Nature) or Wisdom (Survival) check.

hazard.name: Cave Mist Creeper
entries: A fungus that forms layers of red-brown tendrils across the walls of caves, with a large number of crusty white protrusions along its length. A dark green gas seeps from the protrusions, filling up tunnels with a deadly poison. Wherever Cave Mist Creeper grows, it chokes out all other life, and the rotting remains of plants and animals killed by its emissions fertilises new growth. It spreads quickly, and a 10ft area of it can sprout up in a day if it has just a single medium-sized carcass to nourish itself. Cave Mist Creeper grows almost exclusively underground, or otherwise in places very well shaded from wind. Patches can be of any size, but usually branch out over multiple tunnels or other spaces. Quaggoths sometimes live near CMC infested caves as they don't have cause to fear the poison.

A patch of CMC emits gas up to 15ft away. This gas spreads around corners and lightly obscures its area. A creature that enters the gas for the first time on its turn or starts its turn in the gas must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save it takes 33 (6d10) poison damage, or half as much on a successful save. A creature that is holding its breath doesn't need to make a save.

The gas can be hedged out by a moderate or stronger wind, but after 1 minute the gas returns. A 5ft square patch of CMC has an AC of 10 and 5 hitpoints, and is immune to poison and psychic damage. Destroying a patch of CMC doesn't cause the gas to dissipate. Identifying Cave Mist Creeper requires DC 15 Intelligence (Nature) or Wisdom (Survival) check.

hazard.name: Coffin Moss
entries: A deadly moss that grows in wet wilderness, like marshes and moorlands. It does not ordinarily grow underwater, but can survive submerged if the ground it grows on becomes flooded. Appearing at first exactly like normal moss, its actually a carnivorous plant that adheres to and engulfs prey. It grows much thicker than most moss, either appearing as a bush or densely overgrown boulder, or as flat ground when growing in holes and trenches. Close observation of its leaves reveals that dew or moisture is actually a translucent sticky slime, and the distinctive pattern of its ribbed stalk that indicates that it is a spring that can quickly contract. When it digests its prey, it leaves metal and stone alone, leaving a deposit of treasures underneath its bulk, but slowly digests organic matter. Bones take the longest to digest, staying around for months. The stench of rotten flesh is usually one of the only clues someone gets of a nearby clump of Coffin Moss, although this same scent draws in scavengers like crows, rats, and flies, which in turn get caught. Clumps of coffin moss are usually 3 to 4 feet tall, and between 5 and 10 feet wide. Coffin Moss is coated in a toxic slime that induces lethargy and numbness, imposing disadvantage on ability checks, attack rolls, and saving throws based on strength.

When a creature touches a clump of Coffin Moss, it is considered {@condition grappled} by the clump, and it must make a DC 13 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, it is drawn into the clump's space and engulfed. While engulfed the creature is restrained, blinded, deafened, and cannot breathe, as long as it is smaller than the moss clump. A creature grappled or engulfed by the moss can make a DC 13 Strength (Athletics) check to escape. A clump of Coffin Moss has an AC of 10 and 15 hitpoints and is immune to psychic damage. Coffin Moss can't be identified without close examination. A creature must use its action to inspect a clump of Coffin Moss to identify it, which requires a DC 17 Intelligence (Nature) or Wisdom (Survival). A creature with a passive perception of 13 notices a scent of rotting flesh while within 20ft of the Coffin Moss, but cannot accurately determine the source.

hazard.name: Giant Clams
entries: While most clams are harmless filter feeders, some can grow to be so large, up to 10ft across, that they can swallow a person whole. These giant clams are often sought out for the pearls they contain, which correspondingly are much larger than what most clams can produce. They're also used to stash treasure or supplies by aquatic humanoids such as merfolk to be retrieved later, or if magically compelled into obedience they can act as little panic rooms or ambush spots for sea hags. Ordinarily they grow completely submerged, but can rarely be found above water on tidal beaches.

When a small or medium creature moves within 5ft of a Giant Clam or the clam is attacked, it reflexively inhales water, and the nearest creature, then closes. The creature must make a DC 13 Strength (Athletics) check, with advantage if it has a swim speed. On a failed save, it is swallowed by the clam. While swallowed, it has total cover from effects originating outside of the clam, it is blinded, deafened, restrained, cannot breathe, and at the start of each of its turns it takes 6 (2d6) bludgeoning damage as it is crushed. The clam can only have one creature swallowed at a time. A creature inside of the clam or within 5ft of it can make a DC 13 Strength check to force the clam open, which immediately releases any swallowed creatures. A creature moving within 5ft of the clam can avoid causing the clam to close by making a DC 13 Dexterity (Stealth) or Wisdom (Animal Handling) check. A creature can use its action to try and retrieve an object inside of an open Giant Clam by making a DC 13 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check, retrieving the object on a success, but causing the clam to attempt to swallow it on a failure. A Giant Clam is a beast with an AC of 16 while open or 19 while closed and 10 hitpoints. A Giant Clam opens if it dies. No ability check is required to identify a Giant Clam, but a DC 10 Wisdom (Survival) check is required to know they have a tendency to produce large pearls, and also that they can swallow creatures whole.

hazard.name: Pixie Sniffles
entries: A bush that bears brightly coloured floral buds that burst open at the slightest provocation. A single bush bears flowers of multiple colours, usually shades of red, pink, and purple. When the buds pop open, they release a puff of pollen that appears as a shower of golden glitter and the flower makes a sound like a melodious chime being struck. These flowers grow on the material plane but also in the feywild, where most fey creatures are immune to the effects of its pollen, hence the flower's name. Pixies cultivate these flowers as a discreet passive deterrent against intruders, but also because they find its effects on others to be highly amusing.

When a creature touches a Pixie Sniffle bush, it causes a chain reaction of flower buds to pop open, releasing pollen up to 10ft away. Each creature subject to the pollen that isn't a fey must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, its movement is halved and it can't take actions until the end of its next turn, as it is overcome by intense sneezing fits. Pixie Sniffle bushes grow alone or entwined with other plants. They have an AC of 2, 1 hitpoint, and are immune to psychic damage. Identifying a Pixie Sniffle bush requires a DC 13 Intelligence (Nature) or Wisdom (Survival) check.

hazard.name: Pond Snare
entries: A carnivorous plant that grows in slow-moving or stagnant water, such as lakes, ponds, or swamps. It resembles an ordinary water lily in many ways, being rooted at the lakebed and connected to its leaves floating on the surface by a very narrow stalk. The stalk has a large number of branches, some of which reach the surface to additional leaves, but many just exist to help entangle foes. The leaves are circular and about 1 ft in diameter, with a tiny ridge of teeth around the circumference that usually sit just below the waterline. Usually Pond Snare grows in clusters which can blot out small ponds if prevalent enough, and while they grow in water a few feet deep, they can also grow to be up to 50ft long from root to leaf. A Pond Snare's usual prey includes frogs, birds, beavers, and other tiny creatures that might visit the water's surface. They're more than strong enough to ensnare larger prey though.

When a creature touches the leaf, it springs shut, coiling around the creature or whatever part of it made contact, and the stalk contracts quickly, dragging its prey to its death as the web of stalks and branches wrap around it. A creature that makes contact with a Pond Snare is instantly {@condition grappled} and {@condition restrained} by it and pulled up to 20ft downwards. Each round, it is pulled an additional 20ft down until it reaches the bottom of the water. An ensnared creature can use its action to make a DC 17 Dexterity (Acrobatics) or Strength (Athletics) check to escape. Once a Pond Snare has been triggered, it can't be triggered again for 1 hour. A Pond Snare stalk has an AC of 10 and 15 hitpoints, and is immune to psychic damage. Destroying the stalk doesn't kill the Pond Snare unless the root is also killed. A destroyed stalk regrows in 10 days. Pond Snare appears at a glance to be an ordinary water lily, but a creature that uses its action to inspect the Pond Snare or the water it grows in can make a DC 15 Intelligence (Nature) or Wisdom (Survival) check to identify it.

hazard.name: Scylla's Claw
entries: Scylla's Claw: Many types of the peculiar aquatic animals called sea anemones have a venomous sting, and Scylla's Claw is one of the rare ones that are toxic enough to be dangerous to humans. Living in warm tropical seas, they root down on both on the shoreline, around rockpools that are flooded by the tide, and in coral reefs. Their preference for warm water usually means they live in relatively shallow water or near volcanic vents. Their base is a squat cylinder patterned with bright red and white swirls with a swarm of almost translucent white tendrils emerging from within. Young Scylla's Claw have tendrils a few inches long, while older ones can have tendrils extending up to two feet. The poison they carry can instantly overwhelm and kill the many tiny creatures, less than an inch long, that dwell among coral reefs, but in larger creatures instead causes muscles to seize, still a deadly threat to divers.

A creature that touches the tendrils of a Scylla's Claw must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw, becoming {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute on a failed save. While poisoned in this way, the creature is also {@condition paralyzed}. The creature can repeat its saving throw at the end of each of its turns. A DC 13 Intelligence (Nature) check is required to identify a Scylla's Claw.

hazard.name: Brine Pools
entries: A naturally-occurring phenomenon on the ocean floor, where extremely high concentrations of salt create pools of high-density brine that sink in water and create lakes within oceans, with their own surface and shoreline. These brine pools are toxic to most marine life, and usually form near certain high deposits of salt in nearby rocks, where depressions in the sea floor shelter the pools from ocean currents that would disturb them. Most aquatic creatures shun these toxic wastelands, but some folk like sahuagin and sea hags use the natural formations as defence against attackers, while others such as Wastriliths who can survive the salinity can live freely within their depths. Brine Pools vary wildly in size, from tiny ponds to massive lakes miles across.
Creatures that can normally breathe underwater cannot breathe the water in a Brine Pool unless they are also immune to poison.

hazard.name: Lodestones
entries: A rare kind of naturally occurring magnet, Lodestones are formed of the iron ore known as Magnetite. Lodestones are black or very dark brown, small ones have been used to create compasses in ancient times, while large boulder-sized lodestones have often been integrated into ritual stone circles. Most times Lodestones are the result of lightning striking iron-rich rocks. Lodestones can function as fairly strong magnets if large enough.

The magnetic effect of a lodestone large enough to occupy a 5ft cube reaches up to 10ft away from the lodestone. Creatures wearing iron or steel armour have their movement impaired within the magnetic field: the area counts as difficult terrain. Iron or Steel objects that are not being worn or carried within the area are pulled towards the lodestone and adhere to it, including ammunition from ranged weapon attacks that pass through the area, causing such attacks to automatically miss. A creature can make a DC 13 Strength check at the start of its turn to prevent an object being worn or carried from being pulled towards the lodestone.

On a fail, the creature drops the object if it is being carried, or the creature is pulled up to 10ft towards the lodestone if its being worn. Once a magnetic object touches the lodestone, it adheres to the lodestone's surface and a creature must make a DC 13 Strength check as an action to remove it. If an adhered object is being worn by a creature, that creature's speed becomes zero.

hazard.name: Magic Lodestones
entries: Not all lodestones come into being through mundane geography. Other, more potent lodestones are the result of wild magic or contact with planar portals, usually those connected to the elemental planes or feywild. These magic lodestones are sometimes used in rituals by druids and shamans, or to ward areas of importance.

Magic lodestones function identically to mundane ones, but the range of their magnetic properties is usually larger, and they interfere with some magic within 300ft. Within this range, divination magic that reveals the location or direction to a creature or object, as well as the {@spell Sending} spell, fails if either the caster or the target is in the area. Divination sensors cannot enter or percieve anything in the area. Magic that allows for teleportation or planar travel into or out of the area fail.

hazard.name: Natural Gas
entries: In many places underground, flammable gasses can occur naturally and collect in hollow spaces. Odourless and colourless, these gasses are extremely difficult to detect by most creatures and thus pose extreme risk to miners and spelunkers.

Any open flame can ignite concentrated pockets of these gasses, or even sparks as might be caused by steel picks hitting stone. Furthermore, while these gasses are not toxic, they're not breathable either, so where they hedge out oxygen a creature can unknowingly be suffocating as they traverse gas pockets. Miners sometimes bring small creatures like canaries into the mines with them as a means to sense the presence of natural gas; a fragile canary will faint from suffocation long before the average commoner will notice any ill effects, and so acts as a warning to leave the area.

While in an area of natural gas, a creature cannot breathe normally, but cannot sense this until they start to suffer the effects. A creature is unaffected by natural gas for a number of minutes equal to 1 plus its Constitution modifier (minimum of 30 seconds), after which it can survive for a number of rounds equal to its Constitution modifier (minimum of 1 round). At the start of its next turn, it drops to 0 hit points and is dying, and it can't regain hit points or be stabilized until it can breathe again.

Natural gasses are flammable. Any kind of open flame will cause a conflagration that instantly passes through the entire area of natural gas. Every creature in the area when the gasses ignite takes 22 (5d8) fire damage, and flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried are set alight. After combusting, natural gas leaves behind a smoke-like vapour that has both an odour and colour, and continues to prevent a creature from properly breathing.

Natural gas can be hedged out by a moderate wind. It cannot normally be percieved by humanoid senses, but a creature proficient with {@item Alchemist's Supplies} can, with 10 minutes of work and 5gp worth of materials that includes a scrap of paper or cloth, create a strip of material that changes colour when exposed to natural gas. These colour strips can only be used once.

hazard.name: Manes Vapour
entries: Manes are the lowliest of all demons, predated upon even by dretches and quasits. Higher demons use them as mindless hordes of fodder against their foes, a task they excel at not only because of their complete disregard for their own lives, but because no amount of manes lost in battle is a major setback, due to their single unique quality. A slain Manes, unless eaten, does not die. Rather, it dissolves into a cloud of putrid vapour that reforms in one day. When enough Manes are slaughtered in one location, these clouds can become thick enough to block vision and choke living things, and worse things still. Clouds of this sort occur on demonic battlefields in both the lower planes and the sites of demonic incursions to other realms. Often these clouds form pits of mud or slime beneath them as they coalesce into new Manes, first as ichor then slowly attaining shape and flesh, with blood and bodily fluids soaking into the soil or gathering into sticky pools on hard surfaces. The greatest threat though is to living creatures that inhale this foul vapour, not just for its horrid stench, but for the risk that imbuing enough of a demon's essence risks demonic possession.

An area of Manes Vapour is lightly obscured. For each minute that a creature spends in an area, it must make a DC 10 Charisma saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is possessed by a Manes. For 24 hours it is afflicted with intrusive thoughts about violence and chaos. After 24 hours it must repeat the save, and on a fail its Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores become those of a Manes, and its personality is completely overtaken by the Manes. Its alignment becomes chaotic evil. The creature can repeat the saving throw every 24 hours, ending the possession on a success. If the possession ends or the creature dies, it exhales a cloud of green gas which reforms into a Manes after 24 hours.

In places where dense concentrations of Manes are close to reforming, the area of the cloud is also considered difficult terrain. A creature that starts its turn on the ground in the area must make a DC 10 Strength saving throw. On a failed save, its movement is reduced to 0 ft for that turn as it is trapped by sticky goo and half-formed manes reaching out to it.
Identifying a cloud of Manes Vapour requires a DC 15 Intelligence (Arcana) check. A creature that speaks Abyssal makes this check with advantage.
The cloud can also be identified by magic that detects fiends, such as a Paladin's {@classFeature Divine Sense |paladin||1} or a {@spell Detect Evil and Good} spell.

hazard.name: Stain of the Far Realms
entries: The far realms are an especially strange corner of the planes, where basic concepts of reality can stray so far from our own that we don't even have words to describe them. Yet those realms can interact with our own, and invariably leave an aberrant stain on reality. This usually occurs when a fragment of the far realms is brought to the material plane, or when cosmic bodies align such that the two planes can touch. The result permanently marks the material plane, such that life and nature in the affected region can never be the same again. A stained region can be a dozen feet in width or miles across, often slowly growing over time, but a weakening of the aberrant power in the region can cause it to shrink again, although it can never be completely destroyed. Stained regions have an inexplicable magnetism to them. Unintelligent aberrations such as Otyughs, Chokers, Balhannoths, and Gibbering Mouthers are drawn to them.

Plants in the area lose all colouration, slowly turning grey. All plants and animals living in the area become inedible: they taste revolting and provide no nutrition to anything except aberrations. Food brought into the area becomes inedible after 24 hours. For each hour that a humanoid or beast spends in the stained area, it must make a DC 13 Charisma saving throw. If it fails three of these saves, it becomes afflicted with Long-Term Madness (Madness Effects, Page 259-260 Dungeon Master's Guide). Once it becomes afflicted with madness, it doesn't gain any more madness until it fails a further three saves. If it remains within the stained area for 24 hours, it must make a DC 17 Charisma saving throw, becoming afflicted with Indefinite Madness on a failed save. A creature afflicted in this way can only have one form of indefinite madness at a time. Any effect that would cure madness fails within the stained area, although the {@spell calm emotions} spell still suppresses madness as normal. Creatures that spend 7 or more days within the stained area automatically fail this save, and also become physically transformed. Their body turns grey and is warped in disturbing ways, such as eyes moving to unusual places or limbs becoming elongated with additional joints. These changes don't affect its game statistics.

trap.name: Ballista Trap
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 5-10, dangerous threat)}

The big sister of the Crossbow Trap. Typically, ballistae are used to attack or defend castles, so anyone placing one indoors is either expecting serious trouble, or is wildly eccentric. Since a ballista is much harder to conceal than a crossbow, this trap is usually hidden behind a door, and can often shoot straight through it.
{@b Trigger.} A creature that opens a trapped door triggers the trap.
{@b Effect.} The trap makes an attack against the triggering creature. The attack has a +8 attack bonus and deals 16 (3d10) piercing damage on a hit. This attack can't gain advantage or disadvantage.

{@b Countermeasures.} A successful DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check reveals a mechanism attached to the door. A successful DC 15 Desxterity check using thieves tools disables the trip wire, and a check with a total of 5 or lower triggers the trap.

trap.name: Burning Oil Trap
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 1-4, moderate threat)}

A potentially destructive trap that can set fire to its surroundings. A piece of flint is affixed to a moving mechanism, usually a drawer or door, so that it strikes a steel blade when the trapped object is operated, and causes a spark. This spark ignites a pool or container of lantern oil, which is spilled by the same mechanism. Since this trap is designed to start a large fire, its usually placed in locations where the builder of the trap isn't concerned about collateral damage, and especially where escaping the fire could cause an intruder to blunder it more traps. A common use for this trap is to destroy incriminating documents inside a trapped container.
{@b Trigger.} This trap is activated when the door or container is opened.

{@b Effect.} When this trap is activated, it spills enough oil to cover a 10ft square are of ground, and ignites it. The burning oil functions identically to the oil described on page 152 of the Player's Handbook.

{@b Countermeasures.} The trap can be disarmed by dousing the mechanism in water to prevent a spark from catching. Traps of this kind sometimes have a hidden lever which disengages the flint so that the mechanism can be operated normally. The DC to spot the trap is 15, which can be noticed by the scent of oil or the presence of a hidden lever.

trap.name: Electric Water
entries: {@b Magic Trap (level 11-16, dangerous threat)}

This trap uses a set of magical copper electrodes to zap anyone who makes contact with a charged pool of water, which is usually a pool at least 15ft deep but can be as shallow as one inch. The electric current can cause muscles to seize, making this trap especially deadly since it inhibits its victim's ability to escape. The charged water is visibly electrified and crackles with obvious blue sparks.
{@b Trigger.} This trap has no trigger, it is always active. The effect takes place once a creature touches the water.

{@b Effect.} . Any creature that touches the water for the first time on its turn or starts its turn touching the water must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 33 (6d10) lightning damage and is {@condition stunned} until the start of their next turn. On a successful save the creature takes half as much damage and isn't stunned.

{@b Countermeasures.} The trap can be disabled by covering the electrodes with an insulating substance such as dirt or clay. In addition, the water does not conduct the electricity well enough to cause damage if it is frozen.

trap.name: Fish Hook String
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 1-4, moderate threat)}

A basic trap often used by smugglers and thieves in coastal areas due to how simple it is to create. This basic tripwire is augmented by the addition of several large barbed hooks normally used for fishing. These hooks aren't very dangerous but are difficult and painful to remove. A string of fish hooks is usually hidden by low foliage or buried in soft sand, or inside a narrow opening such as a crawlspace or treasure stash. Since simple fish hooks aren't likely to stop an intruder in their tracks, these hooks are usually attached to a bell or some other alarm, or are attached to a discreet seal of some kind (such as paper or wax) that breaks when the line is pulled on to leave evidence of tampering.

{@b Trigger.} This trap is activated by a creature coming into contact with it. For a ground-level string this involves walking over it, for other kinds of line it can involve moving under it or placing one's hands near it.

{@b Effect.} The hooks pierce cloth and slip through gaps in chainmail. A creature that activates this trap takes 1 piercing damage, and is impaled by 2d4 fish hooks. If the trap is anchored to the ground, the creature's speed becomes 0 ft. The hooks can be removed by a creature using its action to make a Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check. The DC of this check equals 10 plus the number of fish hooks. On a success, all hooks are removed. On a failure, a number of hooks are removed equal to the total rolled on the ability check minus 10, and the creature takes 1 piercing damage for each hook that remains. A hook can be removed without needing a skill check or to use your action, but the creature takes 1 piercing damage per hook removed.
{@b Countermeasures.} The DC to spot this trap is 12. This trap can be easily disarmed with a blade by cutting the string, no ability check required.

trap.name: Gong
entries: {@b Magic Trap (level 5-10, dangerous threat)}

Large bells, gongs, and chimes are a fixture in many temples of various denominations. This trap consists of such an instrument magically enchanted to deter intruders. The gong (or other similar instrument) is a Large object that makes a sound when struck with a hammer or pendulum, or when triggered.

{@b Trigger.} The trigger for this trap acts identically to a {@spell glyph of warding} spell: a magical symbol is inscribed on a nearby surface, and when the object covering the symbol is removed, the trap is activated.

{@b Effect.} Once activated, the gong magically begins to ring on its own for 1 minute, and each creature within 30ft of the gong must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 14 (4d6) thunder damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success. Creatures within range of the effect are {@condition deafened} regardless of whether they succeed on the save. A creature within 30ft of the gong must also make this save if it starts its turn in range of the effect or moves into the affected area for the first time on its turn, or if the gong itself is subjected to bludgeoning or thunder damage for the first time on a creature's turn.

{@b Countermeasures.} The trap can be disabled by casting Dispel Magic on the gong, or a creature within 5ft of the Gong can make a DC 15 Intelligence (Arcana) check. A Detect Magic spell reveals Transmutation magic on the bell, and Abjuration magic on the trap's trigger.

trap.name: Greased Stair
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 1-4, moderate threat)}

This trap consists of a single trapped step or rung near the top of a staircase or ladder designed to cause someone to fall. There are two versions of this trap that function similarly. The first uses a lubricant smeared on the relevant step, while the second involves a hinge mechanism that's much harder to spot.
{@b Trigger.} This trap is triggered when a cretaure steps on the trapped stair or rung.

{@b Effect.} The triggering creature must make a DC 13 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check. On a success, nothing happens, but on a fail the creature falls and takes falling damage as normal depending on the distance.

{@b Countermeasures.} The trap can be avoided by skipping the trapped step. A greased stair can be disarmed by washing away the lubricant with water and a cloth, while a hinged stair can be disarmed by wedging a spike into the trapped stair to prevent it from moving. A greased stair can be spotted with a passive perception of 11, as the grease can be seen upon close examination and also has a noticeable aroma. A hinged stair requires a passive perception of 15 to notice a lack of wear on the rung suggesting it isn't used, or marks at the edge of the stair/ladder that indicate where it folds.

trap.name: Psychic Disruptor
entries: {@b Magic Trap (level 5-10, dangerous threat)}
This trap composes of a magic crystal set into a clamp in front of a vertical dish that focuses disorienting psychic energy.
{@b Trigger.} The trap is activated by a pressure plate positioned within the trap's area of effect.

{@b Effect.} When activated, each creature present must roll initiative. The trap emits painful psychic energy in a 60ft cone. Each creature within the cone has disadvantage on all ability checks and attack rolls, and each foot of movement costs two feet of speed, and if it ends its turn in the trap's area it must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw, taking 22 (4d10) psychic damage on a failed save and half as much on a successful one. In addition, a creature that fails this saving throw falls {@condition prone}.

{@b Countermeasures.} The trap can be disabled by removing or destroying the crystal. The crystal is a tiny object with a AC of 15 and 20 hitpoints. It has a vulnerability to bludgeoning and thunder damage, resistance to piercing and slashing, and immunity to all other damage. The crystal can be removed from its clamp by a creature within 5ft of it either with a DC 15 Strength check or a DC 15 Intelligence (Arcana) check. The DC is 17 to spot the pressure plate, and a {@spell Detect Magic} spell reveals an aura of Enchantment magic around the crystal.

trap.name: Razor Blades
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 1-4, moderate threat, dangerous threat with poison)}

This trap simply consists of a few strategically placed blades on the underside of something that requires lifting, such as a window, the lid of a chest, or portcullis, such that when a creature tries to lift the object the blades are pressed into its hands.
{@b Trigger.} This trap is activated when a creature tries to lift the trapped object.

{@b Effect.} The blades deal 5 (2d4) slashing damage to the triggering creature. Some versions of this trap have poison smeared on the blades, which deals an additional 10 (3d6) poison damage if the creature fails a DC 13 Constitution saving throw, or half as much damage on a success.

{@b Countermeasures.} Easy to improvise with little mechanical skill, it is also easy to defeat. The blades will cut through leather but can't slice through chainmail, allowing someone wearing heavy armour to ignore the trap entirely. Similarly, it can be easily opened using another object as leverage, and the thin razor blades can be smashed with a sturdy object such as a crowbar or rock. The DC to spot the blades is 10.

trap.name: Razor Tripwire
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 1-4, moderate threat)}

This simple but brutal trap consists of coils of wire covered in barbs or blades, placed low to the ground. Usually in areas where creatures might be moving quickly, and often concealed by foliage or darkness.
{@b Trigger.} This trap is activated by a creature moving over or through the wire.

{@b Effect.} A creature that trigger this trap must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature's speed is reduced to zero as it is entangled in the wire, it falls {@condition prone}, and it takes 3d4 slashing or piercing damage. An entangled creature can be freed if it or another creature within 5ft of it makes a DC 13 Dexterity (Sleight of Hand) check to untangle the wires, or it takes 1d4 piercing or slashing damage on a failure.

{@b Countermeasures.} The wire can be destroyed. The wire is an object with 15 hitpoints and an AC of 15. A creature that jumps or flies over a trapped space can avoid the trap entirely. The DC to spot the trap is 13.

trap.name: Rigged Lantern
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 1-4, dangerous threat)}
This trap consists of a volatile alchemical mixture placed inside a regular lantern, which is usually affixed to the wall of a dark windowless room.
{@b Trigger.} This trap is activated when the lantern is lit or takes fire damage.

{@b Effect.} The lantern explodes, and each creature within 15ft of it must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 3 (1d6) fire damage and 10 (3d6) piercing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

{@b Countermeasures.} The trap can be disarmed by opening the lantern and removing the explosive substance, no ability check required. A DC 15 Wisdom (Perception) check will allow a creature to notice that the lantern's oil well has been filled with something unusual.

trap.name: Shoving Statue
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 1-4, moderate threat)}

This trap consists of a spring-loaded mechanism concealed inside a statue that resembles a knight bearing a shield, a giant goat, or other design, which forcefully pushes intruders, often into the area of other more dangerous traps such as pits or rolling boulders.
{@b Trigger.} . The trap is triggered by a pressure plate placed in front of the statue.

{@b Effect.} When the trap is activated, the spring mechanism is released, and the statue's appendages are thrown forward. Any creatures in the space in front of it must make a DC 15 Strength saving throw or on a failed save be pushed up to 10ft away from the statue and be knocked {@condition prone}.
{@b Countermeasures.} The DC to spot the pressure plate is 15. Wedging an iron spike or other object under the pressure plate prevents the trap from activating.

trap.name: Slashed Bridge
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 11-16, moderate threat)}

Rope bridges are easy to construct with limited tools and materials, but consequently are also much easier to destroy than a wood or stone bridge. A simple way to trap a rope bridge is to partially cut the rope, shallow so that it doesn't immediately collapse under its own weight, but deep enough that too much extra weight will cause it to snap. Usually a slashed bridge requires at least 300 lb be applied to it before it snaps, such that it usually takes at least two adventurers laden with weapons and equipment to trigger it. In this way, the bridge can be easily crossed one at a time by those who know of the trap.
{@b Trigger.} This trap is activated when the bridge's weight limit is exceeded.

{@b Effect.} The bridge snaps at the point where it was cut. Each creature on the bridge when it snaps can make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw to grab onto the bridge. Failing the saving throw means the creature instantly falls. Succeeding allows the creature to remain on its relative position along the bridge's length, but hanging below the anchor point of the bridge and the ground.

{@b Countermeasures.} Evidence of tampering can be spotted with a Passive Perception of 10 by a creature within 10ft of the slash. A creature can choose to inspect the bridge by making a DC 13 Intelligence (Investigation) check, and on a success, can determine that the bridge is unstable due to sagging at one end, and that it can probably take the weight of one lightly-laden creature, but can't estimate a more specific weight. A {@spell mending} spell targeted at the tampered area will repair the bridge. A creature can also use 15ft of rope to attempt to reinforce the bridge around the weakened point by making a DC 13 Intelligence (Sleight of Hand) check, effectively disarming the trap on a success.

trap.name: Spike Plates
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 5-10, dangerous threat)}

This trap uses a 5ft square plate with several holes across its surface. When activated, spikes thrust out of the holes. This trap is not hidden, but usually a whole room is floored with them, making standing on the ground in the room nearly impossible without being hurt. This trap commonly comes in two varieties: pressure activated and timed.
{@b Pressure Plate}
{@b Trigger.} This version of the trap has the spike plate double as a pressure plate that activates when more than 50 pounds of weight is placed on the pressure plate.
{@b Effect.} When activated, a creature standing on a spike plate must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 6d6 piercing damage on a failed save, and half as much on a successful one.

{@b Countermeasures.} A room tiled with pressure activated plates usually has a path through it consisting of fake spike plates that look identical to the real ones, or has a hidden lever that turns some of the plates off. A DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check can determine which plates are fake or can be turned off. Alternatively, a DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves tools can allow a creature to disarm the trap.
{@b Timed Plate}
{@b Trigger.} This version of the trap is either activated by opening the door to the room, or by a lever in a nearby room.

{@b Effect.} When this trap is activated, each creature present rolls initiative. In this version of the trap, the spike plates thrust out their spikes in a pattern, such as alternating rows or in the shape of a simple picture. On initiative 20 each round, the pattern changes, which might include some spikes retreating into their holes, and others emerging. Timed spike plates that are allowed to cycle through all of their patterns repeat the sequence until the trap is shut off. A creature standing on a spike plate must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 6d6 piercing damage on a failed save, and half as much on a successful one.

{@b Countermeasures.} A DC 15 Intelligence (Investigation) check can allow a creature to deduce the next pattern in the sequence. The trap can be turned off if it was activated by a lever. Alternatively, a DC 15 Dexterity check using thieves tools can allow a creature to disarm the trap, while a DC 20 Intelligence check using Tinkers Tools can be used to change the sequence of patterns.

trap.name: Spring Loaded Door
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 1-4, moderate threat)}
This trap is meant to surprise unwary lockpickers. An ordinary outwards-opening door is fitted with a powerful spring or piston that pushes the door with considerable force when unlocked.
{@b Trigger.} This trap activates when the trapped door is unlocked.
{@b Effect.} A creature next to the door when it is unlocked must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, the creature takes 1d6 Bludgeoning damage and is knocked {@condition prone}.

{@b Countermeasures.} The trap doesn't trigger if a spike is wedged between the door and the frame to prevent it from opening, but it activates once the spike is removed. A DC 13 Strength check can hold the door closed or open it slowly to prevent it from causing damage.

trap.name: Wind Tunnel
entries: {@b Mechanical Trap (level 11-16, moderate threat)}

This trap uses a powerful fan to turn a corridor into a wind tunnel. This kind of wind tunnel is also found when creatures used fans to circulate air, such as bringing fresh air into mineshafts or extracting harmful gasses from toxic environments, with these machines being dangerous to intruders in the vents being a coincidental convenience. The fan sucks air in one way, and pushes it the other. Reversing the direction of the fan's rotation also reverses the flow or air.
{@b Trigger.} The fan is usually running at all times, especially in industrial environments, but can be activated by other trap triggers.

{@b Effect.} The fan's area of effect extends in a 60ft cylinder in each direction, pulling in one end and pushing out the other. The cylinder's diameter is as wide as the fan. Each creature that starts its turn in the line must succeed on a DC 15 Strength saving throw or be pushed 15 feet towards or away from the fan depending on which side it is on. Any creature in the line must spend 2 feet of movement for every 1 foot it moves when moving against the flow of air. The fan disperses gas or vapor, and it extinguishes candles, torches, and similar unprotected flames in the area. It causes protected flames, such as those of lanterns, to dance wildly and has a 50 percent chance to extinguish them. A creature that touches the fan takes  (4d10) slashing damage each time it makes contact with the fan, or if it starts its turn touching the fan.
{@b Countermeasures.} The fan can be stopped if an object is placed in its path. The object takes damage from touching the fan, and if it isn't destroyed, the fan stops.

object.name: Burning Bale
entries: Useful for defending hilltop fortresses and camps, a bale of hay or twigs can be soaked in flammable materials and rolled down hills at attacking forces. Effective on slopes, but loses momentumn quickly on flat ground. A burning bale is propped up onto a mount and a brace is pulled away to release it. It takes one action to load a bale onto the mount, one to ignite it, and one action to release it.
A burning bale burns for a limited time. Each round after being lit, the bale takes 11 (2d10) fire damage, and the flames are extinguished if the bale is reduced to zero hitpoints in this way.

{@b Burning Bale.} The bale rolls off its mount and travels 50ft in a straight line. If the bale is on flat ground when it finishes its move, it stops, but if it is on a downhill slope it moves again each round. The bale can't roll uphill. Each creature in the bale's path when it moves must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 10 (3d6) bludgeoning damage and 11 (2d10) fire damage, and is knocked {@condition prone}. On a successful save, the creature takes half damage and isn't knocked prone, and instead moves into an unoccupied space within 5ft out of the bale's path, if it can. If the bale finishes its movement in a medium or smaller creature's space, that creature is {@condition restrained} until the bale is moved from that space, or its succeeds on a DC 13 Strength (Athletics) check to move into the nearest unoccupied space.

object.name: Burning Glass
entries: A Burning Glass (sometimes called a burning mirror) is a device that uses large lenses and mirrors to concentrate large amounts of sunlight into a small area, with enough intensity to start fires. Small handheld versions of this device can be used for domestic firemaking and heating, but this huge construction is designed as a weapon of war, primarily for use against ships.

Despite the power of this weapon, it has some critical vulnerabilities. The materials used in its construction are vulnerable to heavy blunt strikes as might be inflicted by opposing sieges weapons, and its dependence on being in direct sunlight renders it completely useless at night time or when obscured by severe weather. Cunning spellcasters might use magical sunlight to power the device, such as that created by the {@spell Dawn} spell.

It takes two actions to aim the burning glass. The burning glass applies its effects automatically as soon as it is capable of doing so, and on each subsequent round. If not aimed, it coninues to affect the same point it was last aimed at. Usually a burning glass is covered prior to firing. Uncovering or re-covering a burning glass takes one action.

actionEntries.name: Burning Sunlight
entries: A beam of concentrated sunlight is focused on a single creature or object within 1200 ft. The target must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw, taking 33 (6d10) radiant damage on a failure, and is blinded until the end of its next turn. A creature with the Sunlight Sensitivity or Sunlight Hypersensitivity features makes this save with disadvantage. An object automatically fails the save, and if it isn't being worn or carried, it ignites, taking 7 (2d6) fire damage each round until a creature uses its action to douse the flames.

object.name: Flamethrower
entries: A flamethrower uses magic or complex machinery to shoot a gout of flammable oil over a large distance from its bellows, which is ignited by a torch or metal filament called the pilot light at the end of the nozzle. Extremely potent at incinerating crowds of enemies, even those in heavy armour, and at setting buildings ablaze.

It takes three actions to load a flamethrower, one to light the pilot light, one to aim, and one to fire. A flamethrower can be fired three times before it needs to be reloaded. The pilot light, once lit, doesn't need to be relit unless extinguished.

A flamethrower usually doesn't malfunction, but severe damage can cause dangerous leaks. A flamethrower reduced to 0 hitpoints by fire damage bursts into flames and erupts oil. Each creature within 10ft of the flamethrower must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 17 (5d6) fire damage on a failure, or half as much on a success. The remains of the flamethrower burn for 1 minute, and any creature that touches the burning remains takes 7 (2d6) fire damage.

{@b Throw Flame.} The flamethrower shoots burning oil in a line 60ft long and 5ft wide. Flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried are set alight. Creatures in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 28 (8d6) fire damage and is ignited. While ignited, a creature takes 7 (2d6) fire damage at the start of each of its turns unless it or another creature within 5ft of it uses its action to douse the flames. A creature that succeeds on the saving throw takes half as much damage, and isn't ignited.

actionEntries.name: Throw Flame
entries: The flamethrower shoots burning oil in a line 60ft long and 5ft wide. Flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried are set alight. Creatures in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 28 (8d6) fire damage and is ignited. While ignited, a creature takes 7 (2d6) fire damage at the start of each of its turns unless it or another creature within 5ft of it uses its action to douse the flames. A creature that succeeds on the saving throw takes half as much damage, and isn't ignited.

object.name: Hwacha
entries: The Hwacha is an early gunpowder weapon that composes of several rows of arrows on a rack attached to firework-style rockets all bound by a single fuse, so that lighting one fuse would unleash a hundred or more arrows at once. This weapon is primarily useful against densely-packed infantry: with its wild inaccuracy made up for only by the sheer volume of projectiles it fires and long range, its far from a precision weapon. More advanced forms of this weapon add an extra component to the propellant of the arrows, turning them into incendiary weapons at the cost of reducing the weapon's range due to the extra weight on the arrows.
It takes three actions to load a hwacha, one to aim, and one to fire.

actionEntries.name: Arrow Barrage
entries: Arrows rain down on a point within 400 ft. Each creature within a 30ft cube centred on that point must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 27 (6d8) piercing damage on a failure, or half as much on a success.

actionEntries.name: Incendiary Barrage
entries: Flaming arrows rain down on a point within 300 ft. Each creature within a 30ft cube centred on that point must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 27 (6d8) piercing damage and 14 (4d6) fire damage on a failure, or half as much on a success. Flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried are ignited.

object.name: Mobile Barricade
entries: A wood and iron barricade mounted on wheels, usually with slits for archers to fire from and steps to look over the top. These devices are used to provide cover to troops advancing on fortified positions, as well as a means to quickly erect defenses for an army on the move. They see less use in urban warfare or crowd control, but are still useful for barricading streets against riots or invading forces while still allowing the defenders to advance or adapt as needed, they may be set up in advance of important events or where an important person needs clear passage.
A creature on the inside edge of the barricade can make ranged attacks through the slits, or melee attacks using a reach weapons. A creature on the inside of the barricade has three-quarters cover.

object.name: Ballista (Firework)
entries: In settings with gunpowder technology, ballista bolts can be fitted with fireworks that increase the range of the weapon and detonate shorty after being fired.

attackEntries: {@hit +6} to hit, range 300/1200 ft., one target.
hitEntries: 16 ({@damage 3d10}) piercing damage. Regardless of whether the attack hits, the firework bolt detonates. Each creature within 10ft of the target must make a DC 13 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 (3d6) fire damage on a failure, or half as much on a success.

object.name: Ballista (Harpoon)
entries: The large bolts of a ballista are easily attached to ropes or chains and fitted with barbed heads to create harpoons ideal for attaching to ships and larger creatures such as giants or whales, either to allow creatures to climb along the ropes or to pull the target closer.

attackEntries: {@hit +6} to hit, range 20/200 ft., one target.
hitEntries: 16 ({@damage 3d10}) piercing damage. The harpoon becomes stuck in the target, and is connected to the ballista by a rope or chain. While stuck, the target can't move further from the Ballista than the length of the rope. One or more creatures can pull on the rope to pull the target closer or knock it {@condition prone}, and if the target is a creature it can make a Strength (Athletics) check contested against the creature(s) pulling it to resist being moved or knocked prone. A creature can use its action to make a DC 13 Strength check to remove a stuck harpoon from itself or another harpoon within 5ft of it.

object.name: Cannon (Grapeshot)
entries: Bundles of smaller projectiles, known as Grapeshot, are effective at close-range obliteration of crowds, while also being easier to improvise. An ill-equipped force can stuff a cannon with cutlery and pebbles when they run out of proper ammunition.

actionEntries.name: Grapeshot
entries: Each creature within a 90ft cone must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 44 (8d10) piercing damage, or half as much on a success.

object.name: Cannon (Chain Shot)
entries: Two cannonballs connected by a chain whirl through the air and wrap around their targets, designed for shredding the sails and rigging of ships, they also work well against flying foes.

attackEntries: {@hit +6} to hit, range 240/960 ft., one target.
hitEntries: 27 (5d10) bludgeoning damage. A flying creature hit by this attack falls {@condition prone}.

object.name: Cannon (Rocket)
entries: Fitting the propellant of the cannon into the projectile rather than into the barrel allows it to fire explosive rockets with a shrapnel payload.

attackEntries: {@hit +6} to hit, range 240/960 ft., one target.
hitEntries: 33 (6d10) bludgeoning damage. Regardless of whether the attack hits, the rocket detonates. Each creature within 30ft of the target must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 (3d6) fire damage and 22 (4d10) piercing damage on a failure, or half as much on a success.

object.name: Suspended Cauldron (Acid)
entries: A cauldron is an iron pot suspended so that it can be tipped easily, spilling its contents. Once emptied, a cauldron must be refilled-and its contents must usually be reheated-before it can be used again. It takes three actions to fill a cauldron and one action to tip it.
Acid is an effective alternative to boiling oil, especially against foes resistant to fire or when there are no facilities to heat the oil.

actionEntries.name: Acid
entries: The cauldron pours acid onto a 10-foot-square area directly below it. Any creature in the area must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 10 (2d6) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. A creature that fails its save is also covered in sticky acid, and takes an additional 3 (1d6) acid damage at the start of each of its turns until it uses its action to scrape or wash the acid off.

object.name: Suspended Cauldron (Grease)
entries: A cauldron is an iron pot suspended so that it can be tipped easily, spilling its contents. Once emptied, a cauldron must be refilled-and its contents must usually be reheated-before it can be used again. It takes three actions to fill a cauldron and one action to tip it.

Grease isn't directly harmful to creatures it hits, but it leaves a slippery puddle behind that impedes anyone trying to charge past the defenders as they re-arm the cauldron, as well as being highly effective against foes trying to breach a fortified position by climbing ladders.

actionEntries.name: Grease
entries: The cauldron pours slippery grease onto a 10-foot-square area directly below it. The area becomes difficult terrain, which persists for 10 minutes, or until it is washed away. Any creature in the area when the cauldron is used, or who moves into the area for the first time on its turn must make a DC 15 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or fall {@condition prone}.

object.name: Suspended Cauldron (Ice Water)
entries: A cauldron is an iron pot suspended so that it can be tipped easily, spilling its contents. Once emptied, a cauldron must be refilled-and its contents must usually be reheated-before it can be used again. It takes three actions to fill a cauldron and one action to tip it.

Icy cold water is very easy to source in certain climates, making it an economical choice of weapon. Against foes attacking in cold windy weather, it can quickly cause hypothermia, and leave a slippery hazard as it freezes on surfaces.

actionEntries.name: Ice Water
entries: The cauldron pours ice-cold water onto a 10ft-foot-square area directly below it. Creatures in the area are affected by {@hazard Frigid Water} (DMG page 110) until they spend at least 10 minutes warming themselves near a source of heat, or until they are dried. If the ambient temperature of the area is below 0 degrees Celsius (or 32 degrees Fahrenheit), the water freezes on surfaces. The area becomes difficult terrain, and creatures that enter the area for the first time on their turn must succeed on a DC 10 Dexterity (Acrobatics) check or fall {@condition prone}.

object.name: Suspended Cauldron (Sewage)
entries: A cauldron is an iron pot suspended so that it can be tipped easily, spilling its contents. Once emptied, a cauldron must be refilled-and its contents must usually be reheated-before it can be used again. It takes three actions to fill a cauldron and one action to tip it.

Though unlikely to cause serious harm, sewage is best used as a deterrent to demoralise a foe or to cause nausea that reduces the effectiveness of their assault. Often used as a desperation measure by besieged foes that have expended their more dangerous fluids.

actionEntries.name: Sewage
entries: The cauldron pours foul-smelling sewage onto a 10ft area directly below it. Any creature in the area must make a DC 15 Consitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is poisoned for 1 minute.

object.name: Trebuchet (Flaming Ball)
entries: A trebuchet is a powerful catapult that throws its payload in a high arc, so it can hit targets behind cover. Before the trebuchet can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes two actions to load the weapon, two actions to aim it, and one action to fire it.

Hay soaked with oil can be set alight prior to firing. Igniting the hay takes place during the action used to load the weapon. Less effective at destroying fortifications than a simple stone except those made of wood.

attackEntries: {@hit +5} to hit, range 300/1,200 ft. (can't hit targets within 60 feet of it), one target.

object.name: Trebuchet (Corpses)
entries: A trebuchet is a powerful catapult that throws its payload in a high arc, so it can hit targets behind cover. Before the trebuchet can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes two actions to load the weapon, two actions to aim it, and one action to fire it.

Catapults make for an excellent delivery method for primative biological warfare. festering corpses of humanoids or animals are a potent weapon of intimidation as well as a vector for disease that is especially effective during drawn-out sieges. Normally these diseases are represented by {@disease Sewer Plague} (described on page 257 of the DMG) but can be almost any sort of disease, including ones found in this document such as {@disease Boiling Blood|MADMT} or {@disease Blightpus|MADMT}.

attackEntries: {@hit +5} to hit, range 300/1,200 ft. (can't hit targets within 60 feet of it), one target.
hitEntries: 14 (4d6) bludgeoning damage. A creature hit with this attack, or who handles the corpse, must make a Constitution saving throw against a disease of the DM's choice (typically Sewer Plague). If the corpse comes into contact with water, that water source becomes contaminated with this disease.

object.name: Trebuchet (Insect Hive)
entries: A trebuchet is a powerful catapult that throws its payload in a high arc, so it can hit targets behind cover. Before the trebuchet can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes two actions to load the weapon, two actions to aim it, and one action to fire it.
Catapults make for an excellent delivery method for primative biological warfare. Baskets or hives full of stinging insects can quickly diminish enemy morale and cause disarray among the defenders

attackEntries: {@hit +5} to hit, range 300/1,200 ft. (can't hit targets within 60 feet of it), one target.
hitEntries: A hostile {@filter Swarm of Insects |bestiary|source=|type=beast|tag=swarm|miscellaneous=|Intelligence=[1]} appears in the targeted space and attacks the nearest creature.

object.name: Trebuchet (Blade Wheel)
entries: A trebuchet is a powerful catapult that throws its payload in a high arc, so it can hit targets behind cover. Before the trebuchet can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes two actions to load the weapon, two actions to aim it, and one action to fire it.
Wheels or barrels embedded with blades can roll for a time after being hurled, they lack the impact of a boulder but are much better at slicing through tightly-packed infantry.

actionEntries.name: Blade Wheel
entries: The wheel lands in a space within 600 ft of the Trebuchet, and rolls forward. Each creature in a 5 ft wide, 60 ft long line originating from the point of landing must make a DC 15 Dexterity saving throw, taking 22 (4d10) slashing damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

object.name: Mangonel (Flaming Ball)
entries: A mangonel is a type of catapult that hurls heavy projectiles in a high arc. This payload can hit targets behind cover. Before the mangonel can be fired, it must be loaded and aimed. It takes two actions to load the weapon, two actions to aim it, and one action to fire it.

attackEntries: +5 to hit, range 200/800 ft. (can't hit targets within 60 feet of it), one target.
