item.name: Blackout Brew
entries: A creature subject to this poison must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. If it fails, the poison takes effect and ends once the creature finishes a long rest. A creature affected by this poison suffers no immediate effects, but once the poison ends, the creature immediately forgets everything it experienced while under the poison's effects. A creature retains its memory if the poison was cured via magic before it expired naturally. A {@spell Greater Restoration} spell can restore a creature's memory.

item.name: Carrot Soup Special
entries: A creature exposed to this poison must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it is poisoned for 1 minute. It can repeat this save at the end of each of its turns. While poisoned in this way, it cannot take actions or reactions, and it's movement is halved. It wastes its turns vomiting uncontrollably. If the creature is currently under the effect of an ingested poison or potion that it imbibed within the past hour, the effects of that poison or potion end.

item.name: Concentrated Capsaicin
entries: A creature subjected to this poison feels an overwhelming burning sensation its mouth. It must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw, becoming poisoned on a failure for 10 minutes. In addition, it must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw at the start of each of its turns. On a failed save, cannot speak until the start of its next turn. This poison can be ended early if a creature uses its action to rinse out its mouth with a liquid such as water, milk, or ale.

item.name: Cyanide Pill
entries: This extremely bitter poison is almost impossible not to notice when tasted, making it difficult to slip into food unnoticed. This pill has no effect unless crushed. A creature that swallows this poison must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw, which is can choose to fail by properly ingesting the poison, if it knows how. The creature takes 42 (12d6) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one.

item.name: Death's Slumber
entries: A creature affected by this poison must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw, taking 14 (4d6) poison damage on a failed save or half as much on a success. If a creature fails its save, or is reduced to 0 hp, it becomes unconscious and stable for 1 hour, or until this poison is cured. To most outward inspection, the creature appears to be dead. A DC 20 Wisdom (Medicine) check is required to determine that the creature is still alive.

item.name: Ghost's Touch
entries: This powerful anesthetic is usually used during surgery. A creature subjected to this poison must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save it loses it's sense of touch and pain, though it's other senses such as taste and balance are unaffected. As such, it is unaware of being injured by attacks it cannot see, and won't wake up if taking damage while sleeping. In addition, the affect creature's concentration on a spell cannot be broken as a result of taking damage.

item.name: Itching Powder
entries: A creature subjected to this poison feels an extreme itching sensation. It must make a DC 10 Constitution saving throw at the start of each of its turns. If it succeeds on 5 saving throws, the effect ends. On a failure, it has disadvantage on all attack rolls and ability checks and its speed is halved until it or another creature uses its action to thoroughly scratch the itch for relief. In addition, a creature that fails this save also loses its concentration if it was concentrating on a spell.

item.name: Laughing Gas
entries: A creature subjected to this poison must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save it becomes poisoned for 1 minute and begins to experience of calmness and euphoria, accompaned by fits of laughing or giggling. An affected creature becomes indifferent to creatures around it unless it takes damage. In addition, any effect that causes the target to be frightened is suppressed.

item.name: Psilocybin
entries: This poison is found in common fungi colloquially known as Magic Mushrooms. A creature subject to this poison must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it begins to hallucinate, and is poisoned. After every 10 minutes that passes, it must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw. Once it succeeds on three saving throws, the poison ends. A creature that succeeds on its initial save must still repeat the save every 10 minutes, but suffers no effects of the poison until it fails at least one. Each time it fails a saving throw, the hallucinations get more extreme. Roll on the table below or choose an effect each time a creature fails its saving throw. A creature can suffer from any number of effects simultaneously. If a creature rolls and gains an effect that it already has, it gains a second instance of that effect if applicable, otherwise nothing happens.

entries.caption: Psilocybin hallucinations
rows: The creature's mind becomes easily manipulated by outside forces. It automatically fails saving throws and ability checks to determine the true nature of an illusion.
The creature's perception of scale changes. It percieves itself or another creature be be one size larger or smaller than it really is.
The creature starts to see double. It percieves one enemy as having the effects of the {@spell Mirror Image} spell.
The creature believes it can understand the speech of animals, and be understood in response.
The creature believes itself to have gained heightened awareness and empathy. It automatically fails Wisdom (Insight) and (Perception) checks, but alway believes it has succeeded.
The creature believes that one inanimate object has come alive. The creature is frightened of that object.

item.name: Quickbleed
entries: A creature subjected to this poison must make a DC 15 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, it is affected by a potent blood thinner. Each time the affected creature takes piercing or slashing damage while under the effects of this poison, including from the triggering attack, it bleeds profusely from the wound. The creature takes 3 (1d6) necrotic at the start of each of its turns, with an additional 3 (1d6) damage for each additional wound recieved. A creature can use its action on its turn to attempt to staunch any wounds by making a DC 10 Wisdom (Medicine) check, which ends all bleeding on a success, but does not cure the poison. Regaining hitpoints from magical healing also closes any bleeding wounds. At the end of each of its turns, a creature can repeat its saving throw against this poison, ending the effect on a success.

item.name: Stingeye
entries: This poison is usually found on toxic mushrooms. A creature subjected to this poison must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw. On a failed save, Its eyes become particularly sensitive to bring light for 8 hours. It has disadvantage on attack rolls and Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on sight when it, the target of the attack, or whatever is is trying to perceive is in bright light. In addition, whenever the creature enters an area of bright light for the first time on it's turn or starts its turn there, it must make a DC 12 Constitution saving throw. On a failure, it becomes {@condition blinded} until the start of its next turn. Once a creature has attempted this save, it doesn't need to do so again until it has entered an area of dim light or darkness.

item.name: Ten Step Death
entries: A creature that comes in contact with this poison suffers no immediate effect. Once the creature takes ten steps, it must make a DC 17 Constitution saving throw, taking 31 (9d6) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much on a success.

For a medium humanoid at a normal relaxed walking pace, 10 steps is approximately 20 ft. A creature in combat is likely to be taking longer strides, and a small creature likely has a shorter stride than a medium creature, so you may wish to rule a different distance for 10 steps depending on the circumstances.

item.name: Theif's Red Hand
entries: This poison is colourless, but reacts upon contact with skin. A creature subject to this poison must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw, taking 5 (2d4) poison damage on a failure, or no damage on  a success. Regardless of the outcome of the save, the section of skin that made contact with the poison turns a bright red-pink. The mark remains until the poison is cured. A creature can repeat the saving throw against this poison whenever it finishes a long rest, ending the effect on a success. Attempting to wash the mark off by ordinary means does not work, and simply causes painful irritation. A creature that attempts to scrub or apply soap to the red mark must make a DC 13 Constitution saving throw, taking 5 (2d4) poison damage on a failure.

monster.name: Awakened Shroud Vine Shrub
languages: On language known by its creator

trait.name: False Appearance (Awakened Shrub)
entries: While the awakened shrub remains motionless, it is indistinguishable from a normal shrub.

action.name: Rake
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 1} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}1 ({@damage 1d4 - 1}) slashing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw against Shroud Vine infection.

Shroud Vine bushes grow into eerie silhouettes of the creature that spawned them, but are otherwise normal bushes. Thus, they can be targeted by any magic that affects plants, such as the *Awaken* spell.

monster.name: Shroud Vine Druid
languages: can communicate simple ideas with plants

trait.name: Contagious Thorns
entries: Once on a turn, if a creature takes damage from the Druid's melee weapon attacks, Thorn Whip, or Thornhide, it must make a {@dc 13} Constitution saving throw, becoming infected with Shroud Vine on a failed save.

trait.name: Thornhide
entries: A creature that grapples the Druid takes 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage.

spellcasting.name: Spellcasting
headerEntries: The druid is a 4th-level spellcaster. Its spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save {@dc 12}, +4 to hit with spell attacks). It has the following druid spells prepared:

action.name: Quarterstaff
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) bludgeoning damage, or 6 ({@damage 1d8 + 2}) bludgeoning damage and 2 ({@damage 1d4}) piercing damage with shillelagh or if wielded with two hands.

action.name: Thorn Whip (Cantrip)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 2} to hit, reach 30 ft., one target. {@h}3 ({@damage 1d6}) piercing damage, and if the target is Large or smaller it is pulled up to 10ft towards the druid.

While Shroud Vine is an insidous blight to most people, some Druids see it as a means of connecting with nature, and form a symbiotic relationship with the parasite, and wield it as a weapon against their enemies.

trait.name: Blightpus eruption
entries: The first time the Kobold takes bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage, Blightpus pustules erupt across its body. Each creature within 5ft of the Kobold must make a {@dc 12} Dexterity saving throw,  taking 6 ({@damage 2d6}) acid damage on a failed save, or half as much on a successful one. The kobold automatically fails the save.

trait.name: Pack Tactics
entries: The kobold has advantage on an attack roll against a creature if at least one of the kobold's allies is within 5 feet of the creature and the ally isn't {@condition incapacitated}.

trait.name: Sunlight Sensitivity
entries: While in sunlight, the kobold has disadvantage on attack rolls, as well as on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Dagger
entries: {@atk mw,rw} {@hit +4} to hit, reach 5 ft. or range 20/60 ft., one target. {@h}4 ({@damage 1d4 + 2}) piercing damage.

Kobolds dwelling in the underdark are at great risk of Blightpus outbreaks due to their cramped lairs and communal living. Infected kobolds are likely to charge recklessly at threats, sacrificing themselves to use their infection against enemies of the tribe.

trait.name: Keen Smell
entries: The tumourous cave bear has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on smell.

trait.name: Tumourous Regeneration
entries: The bear regains 10 Hit Points at the start of its turn. If the bear takes acid or fire damage, this trait doesn't function at the start of the bears's next turn. The bear dies only if it starts its turn with 0 Hit Points and doesn't Regenerate.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The bear makes two attacks: one with its bite and one with its claws.

action.name: Bite
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}9 ({@damage 1d8 + 5}) piercing damage.

action.name: Claw
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) slashing damage.

When wildlife or monsters ingest troll meat, they risk contracting Contagious Troll Tumours. While their increased resilience is a temporary boon that may lead to them dominating the local ecosystem and hedging out rivals, the disease will eventually overcome them, leading to the birth of a new troll.

trait.name: Horrid reflection
entries: If a creature starts its turn where it can see the Noble's reflection, it must make a {@dc 10} Wisdom saving throw, becoming Frightened on a failed save. It can repeat this saving throw at the end of each of its turns. A creature that succeeds on this save is immune to this trait for 24 hours.

action.name: Rapier
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +3} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d8 + 1}) piercing damage.

reaction.name: Parry
entries: The noble adds 2 to its AC against one melee attack that would hit it. To do so, the noble must see the attacker and be wielding a melee weapon.

Of the people likely to be cursed in this way, nobles are especially prime targets as they depend so heavily on their reputation, and the terror of having one's true nature revealed can eat away at them. Nonetheless, some villains aren't afraid of their wicked nature, but their foulness terrifies others, leaving them to fester in evil isolated from others.

trait.name: Shapechanger (Imp)
entries: The imp can use its action to polymorph into a beast form that resembles a rat (speed 20 ft.), a raven (20 ft., fly 60 ft.), or a spider (20 ft., climb 20 ft.), or back into its true form. Its statistics are the same in each form, except for the speed changes noted. Any equipment it is wearing or carrying isn't transformed. It reverts to its true form if it dies.

trait.name: Devil's Sight
entries: Magical darkness doesn't impede the imp's darkvision.

trait.name: Magic Resistance
entries: The imp has advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

trait.name: Two-faced
entries: The imp has advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks and on saving throws against being {@condition blinded}, {@condition charmed}, {@condition deafened}, {@condition frightened}, {@condition stunned}, and knocked {@condition unconscious}. In addition, whenever the Imp tells a truth, its second face will lie. If it tells a lie, its second face will tell the truth.

action.name: Invisibility (Quasit)
entries: The imp magically turns {@condition invisible} until it attacks, or until its {@status concentration} ends (as if {@status concentration||concentrating} on a spell). Any equipment the imp wears or carries is {@condition invisible} with it.

action.name: Sting (Bite in beast form)
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 5} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}5 ({@damage 1d4 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target must make on a {@dc 11} Constitution saving throw, taking 10 ({@damage 3d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

As befitting their role as tempters and deceivers, devils are more likely than anyone to be cursed with two faces. Some come under this kind of curse as a result of clerics or divine entities that oppose fiends, other devils are cursed as punishment by their superiors.

trait.name: Earth Glide
entries: The elemental can burrow through nonmagical, unworked earth and stone. While doing so, the elemental doesn't disturb the material it moves through.

trait.name: Siege Monster
entries: The elemental deals double damage to objects and structures.

trait.name: Lodestone
entries: The elemental is partially made of lodestone: it projects a magnetic field up to 10ft away. Creatures wearing iron or steel armour have their movement impaired within the magnetic field: the area counts as difficult terrain. Iron or Steel objects that are not being worn or carried within the area are pulled towards the elemental and adhere to it, including ammunition from ranged weapon attacks that pass through the area, causing such attacks to automatically miss creatures that aren't the elemental. A creature can make a {@dc 13} Strength check at the start of its turn to prevent an object being worn or carried from being pulled towards the elemental.

On a fail, the creature drops the object if it is being carried, or the creature is pulled up to 10ft towards the elemental if its being worn. Once a magnetic object touches the elemental, it adheres to the elemental and a creature must make a {@dc 13} Strength check as an action to remove it. If an adhered object is being worn by a creature, that creature's speed becomes zero, and if the creature is Large or smaller it moves with the elemental.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The elemental makes two slam attacks.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 8} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}14 ({@damage 2d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage, and if the target is wearing metal armour it adheres to the elemental.
Sometimes the forces that create  Lodestones can also give rise to elemental creatures. They are potent guardians of druidic temples, especially against foes that wield metal.

trait.name: Lightning Absorption
entries: Whenever the shambling mist mound is subjected to lightning damage, it takes no damage and instead regains a number of hit points equal to the lightning damage dealt.

trait.name: Poison Aura
entries: A creature that starts its turn within 15ft of the mound  must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw. On a failed save it takes 33 ({@damage 6d10}) poison damage, or half as much on a successful save. A creature that is holding its breath doesn't need to make a save.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The shambling mound makes two slam attacks. If both attacks hit a Medium or smaller target, the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 14}), and the shambling mound uses its Engulf on it.

action.name: Slam
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 7} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Engulf (Shambling Mound)
entries: The shambling mist mound engulfs a Medium or smaller creature {@condition grappled} by it. The engulfed target is {@condition blinded}, {@condition restrained}, and unable to breathe, and it must succeed on a {@dc 14} saving throw at the start of each of the shambling mist mound's turns or take 13 ({@damage 2d8 + 4}) bludgeoning damage. If the shambling mist mound moves, the engulfed target moves with it. The shambling mist mound can have only one creature engulfed at a time.

Shambling mounds accumulate all kinds of plant matter as they devour their way through the wilderness. CMC normally stays static, feeding on the carrion its vapours kill, and ordinarily wouldn't fare well with mobility. However, a Shambling Mound generates enough carrion by itself that the fungus can easily survive.

trait.name: Keen Sight
entries: The roc has advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The roc makes two attacks: one with its beak and one with its talons.

action.name: beak
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 10 ft., one target. {@h}27 ({@damage 4d8 + 9}) piercing damage.

action.name: Talons
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit 13} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}23 ({@damage 4d6 + 9}) slashing damage, and the target is {@condition grappled} (escape {@dc 19}). Until this grapple ends, the target is {@condition restrained}, and the roc can't use its talons on another target.

action.name: Flamethrower
entries: The flamethrower shoots burning oil in a line 60ft long and 5ft wide. Flammable objects in the area that aren't being worn or carried are set alight. Creatures in the area must make a {@dc 15} Dexterity saving throw. On a failed save, it takes 28 ({@damage 8d6}) fire damage and is ignited. While ignited, a creature takes 7 ({@damage 2d6}) fire damage at the start of each of its turns unless it or another creature within 5ft of it uses its action to douse the flames. A creature that succeeds on the saving throw takes half as much damage, and isn't ignited.

Rocs, like crows, can learn how to use tools, so this flamethrower device is activated by a simple switch that the Roc can operate itself. The False Dragon is an attempt to create a flying artillery weapon with the might of a dragon, capable of devestating fly-by strafing runs, but one that also won't grow up to be an intelligent titan that can resent its captivity. Only two kinds of people would create a False Dragon: people know know all there is to know about Rocs, and people who know nothing about Rocs.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The giant makes two greatclub attacks. Alternatively, it can make one Sewage Pot attack followed by one Greatclub or Rock attack.

action.name: Greatclub
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +8} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}18 ({@damage 3d8 + 5}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Rock
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit 2} to hit, range 60/120 ft., one target. {@h}15 ({@damage 3d10 - 1}) bludgeoning damage.

action.name: Sewage Pot (1/day)
entries: The giant pours foul-smelling sewage onto a 10ft area adjacent to it. Any creature in the area must make a {@dc 15} Consitution saving throw. On a failed save, the creature is {@condition poisoned} for 1 minute.

Hill Giants are notoriously filthy, and have no dignity in battle. If you think you've caught a giant off-guard in the latrine, you're in for a revolting lesson. A hill giant has no shame in tossing the contents of its chamber pot at attackers, then clubbing the unfortunate creature with the pot, or hurling it at foes outside of the splash zone.

monster.name: Venomous Assassin
languages: Thieves' cant plus any two languages

trait.name: Assassinate
entries: During its first turn, the assassin has advantage on attack rolls against any creature that hasn't taken a turn. Any hit the assassin scores against a {@quickref Surprise|PHB|3|0|surprised} creature is a critical hit.

trait.name: Evasion
entries: If the assassin is subjected to an effect that allows it to make a Dexterity saving throw to take only half damage, the assassin instead takes no damage if it succeeds on the saving throw, and only half damage if it fails.

trait.name: Sneak Attack (1/day)
entries: The assassin deals an extra 14 ({@dice 4d6}) damage when it hits a target with a weapon attack and has advantage on the attack roll, or when the target is within 5 feet of an ally of the assassin that isn't {@condition incapacitated} and the assassin doesn't have disadvantage on the attack roll.

action.name: Multiattack
entries: The assassin makes two shortsword attacks.

action.name: Shortsword
entries: {@atk mw} {@hit +6} to hit, reach 5 ft., one target. {@h}6 ({@damage 1d6 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 24 ({@damage 7d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one.

action.name: Light Crossbow
entries: {@atk rw} {@hit +6} to hit, range 80/320 ft., one target. {@h}7 ({@damage 1d8 + 3}) piercing damage, and the target must make a {@dc 15} Constitution saving throw, taking 24 ({@damage 7d6}) poison damage on a failed save, or half as much damage on a successful one. In addition, The creature takes 3 ({@dice 1d6}) necrotic at the start of each of its turns, with an additional 3 ({@damage 1d6}) damage for each additional wound recieved. A creature can use its action on its turn to attempt to staunch any wounds by making a {@dc 10} Wisdom (Medicine) check, which ends all bleeding on a success. Regaining hitpoints from magical healing also closes any bleeding wounds. At the end of each of its turns, a creature can repeat its saving throw against this poison, ending the effect on a success.

bonus.name: Cyanide Pill
entries: The assassin instantly takes takes 42 ({@damage 12d6}) poison damage.

Poison is an incredibly potent tool for assassination. Some assassins master the art of using poisons, and may pay tribute to gods of poison and death in order to learn their arts. Wyvern venom is common for its high toxicity, but some assassins use other mixtures. Quickbleed is useful against foes that may try to flee or take cover, as they can bleed to death even after leaving the assassin's sights. Assassins also know that they could suffer terrible fates if captured alive so carry cyanide pills to ensure they cannot be tortured, often concealed in a false tooth.
